CHAPTER I INTRODUCTION The development of the study on the standard of living and t'he cost of living in Japan is comparatively reCent. Scarcely a dozen years ago, the investigation of subjects relating to elconomic consumption was in an embryonic stage. In 1918, when my thesis on "The Standard of Living in Japan"1 was published by the Johns Hopkins Press, certain economic journals in western countries greeted it with the observation that it was the first research relative to economic consumption in Japan.2 Since then, notable studies in the other fields of economics have been published almost in profusion. However none of the treatises (on the subject relating Ito the Japanese' standard of living have, to the best of my belief, appeared as yet, in English, German or French. Even in Japanese the works in this field are very limited and we can recall only a few reports worth mentioning as being investigations covering a larger field and Carried on in a scientific way.3 In 1929—1930, a memorahle investigation was conducted by the Gov¬ ernment Statistical Bureau. It is Ithej most valuable and extensive work on the standard of living ever undertaken in Japan. The study covers a total of 5,455 families, including 1,575 families of salaried people, 3,210 wage-earners' families and those of 670 farmers. Those studies were carefully selected from among such families having from two to six memhers each and wkh monthly incomes of less than ¥200. At the request of the government authorities each of them, from September, 1926, to" August, 1927, undertook to keep ,a detailed record of daily expenditures. Three volumes of Ithe report have already heen issued 'and a final Volume is due sometime this year.4 1. Johns Hopkins University Studies in Historical and Political Science, Series XXXVI, No. 1. 2. Progress in ithe study of the standard of living has, on the whole, been tomparatively slow in Japan. This is chiefly due to the tradition.; 1 Japanese attitude toward economic life which came to be held in very low esteem, presumably as a result of overstressing the spiritual aspects of life. In former times peasants, wiage^ earners, ,and ihose whose standards of living were at the bare subsistence level were taught to 'content themselves with their predestined lot. Under the influence of such fatalism even the intel¬ lectual classes were not aroused to the importance of making any study of the standard of living. A different situation exists to'day. It is interesting to observe the changes that have taken place in the social attitude, toward the problems oif economic consumption. The cry for the betterment of elconomic life is heard on all si'des. Even those who have regular employment find their incomes insufficient notwithstanding t'he fact that they may look twice at every penny before they spend it. Under these circumstances there arose more comprehensive efforts to measure the changes in the cost of living. Such Calculation calls for: "(i) more or less accurate information on wfiat people buy to satisfy the daily needs of subsistence; (2) accurate information with regard t'o the prices which consumers must pay for the articles and services which enter into the cost of living."5 The cost of living, 'hoiwever, must be distinguished from the standard o'f living. A low cost of living does not signify necessarily a low standard olf living. For economic progress it is even desirable thalt the (cost of living should be low and the standard of living high. The purpose of this study is t'o secure a picture of t'he present situation of economic living in Japan among various groups of Japanese; to determine what constitutes an efficient standard of living in Japan; and then wbat will be the best possible means of raising the present standard 'of living to a standard of efficiencv. 5. National Industrial Conference Board: The Cost of Living in the United States, 1914-1927, p. 1.

, CHAPTER II If: THE THEORY OF THE STANDARD OF LIVING i. The Standard of Living and the Cost of Living ' The standard of living is the expression of the complex thought of thalt measure of living conditions which greatly differs according to the differences of the individual, the time and the place. "It is, in essence, a psychological thing, a concept more or less definite, represented in material life by those nelcessaries and comforts which a man has become accustomed to regard as his right and without which he would not consider life worth while."1 Evidently, the standard of living and the tost 'of living are, though often confused, not the same thing. The former "is a relative phrase depending not upon the amount of income and expendiltures of a family but also on its attitude toward life.......A family with a small income frequently has a higher standard and' lives more comfortably than another family with a much larger income."2 2. The Concept of Standard of Living The confusion as to the concept of the standard of living mainly arose from the fact that it depends on three conditions; namely, individual, terri¬ torial and chronological. Even when care is taken to treat the subject in their definite limits of place and time, the individual conditions seem almost infintely variable because they 'are governed by personal taste, character, education, religion, society, wealth, etc. Thus investigators of the standard of living must often feel as if tthey were thrown into hopeless confusion, and their conclusions will be nothing more than that "every man has his own standard of living."3 Notwithstanding this confusion and difficulty, if we proceed by the proper method of investigation, a certain definite standard of living may be discernible through the maze of facts. That this standard can be deter¬ mined is possible for the following reasons: (I) A certain .common nature of man as a human being produces, consciously or unconsciously, obvious similarity in his economic activities in spite of a wide diversity in his outward manner of living. (2) Owing to the fact that "man is a social animal," he instinctively 1. H. P. Shearman: Practical Economics, 2nd ed., p. 409. 2. L. B. More; Wage-Earners' Budgets, p. 123. 3. F. H. Streightoff: Standard of living among the industrial people of America, p.

creates many social relations, and a process of social assimilation is all the time at work. (3) Men are, by nature, imitative of one another. This inclination of human nature is always working physiologically. Whether voluntary or involuntary, this imitation results in a great degree of uniformity. This uniformity of human activities aids in the scientific research of the standard of living. Since the nature o'f this investigation is so complicated we must begin with the study of the origin of all the activities of economic life; namely, human wants. Marshall has well said that "the term the standard of life is here taken to mean the standard oi activities adjusted to wants."4 Cornish also states that "the standard of life of a family or an individual represents the number and character of wants customarily satisfied."0 Ely goes still further by saying "the number and character of the wants which a man considers more important than marriage and family constitute his standard of life."6 Really, human activities which are constituents of the standard of living are nothing more than expressions of wants. So, in order to enter into an analytical study of the subject, let us make an approach by discussing the divisions of want. Roscher's well known classification of wants is a three-fold division: Natur = , Anstands = und Luxusbedurfnisse (necessity, decency, and luxury).7 Yet we must remember that, it is now more than three quarters of a century since the publication of his valuable book in 1854, and that during that period a unique progress of civilization has taken place. Human wants too, in that space of time, have made remarkable strides both in quality and quantity. Simple ways of living, however inexpensive they may be, will be no longer considered as economical in the present age of "efficiency first." Naturally, the conception of luxury is now so modified as to include two ideas: first, the wants for "comfort," and secondly, the wants for "luxury proper." I thus use a four-fold division: (1) necessity, (2) decency, (3) comfort or efficiency, (4) luxury. 3. The Pauper Standard of Life The "want for necessity" is the feeding of deficiency in those things necessary for bare existence. It exhibits itself chiefly in the desire for the food, shelter, 'and clothing which are physiologically necessary to prevent 4. A. Marshall: Principles of Economics, 1916, p. 689. S. Comish: The Standard of Living, p. 62. 6. R. T. Ely: Principles of Economics, 1922, p. 438. 7. W. Roscher: Grundlagen der Nationalokonomie, 26th ed. p. 1.

physical deterioration. The mode and scale of activities adjusted to the wants for necessity will be termed the pauper standard of life, or primitive life standard. The life of aborigines does not generally extend much beyond this standard. They are contended if their wants for bare subsistence are satisfied. According to the view of modern life, the people on this standard are only in a state of existence and not that of living. The numher of people belonging to this group in Japan as well as in a rich country like America is surprisingly great. Parmelee says "We have plenty of evidence that the number of those who do not even reach the lower minimum standard of living is very great, probably exceeding 10% of the population."8 The nature of their living conditions is well stated by Prof. Hollander in his remarkable book, "The Abolition of Poverty,"9 thus, "There are great hodies of people in country and in city who from birth have less than enough food, clothing, and shelter; who from childhood must toil long and hard to secure even that inefficient amount; who can benefit little from the world's advance in material co'mfort and in spir'tual beauty, because theirl bodies are undernourished, their minds are overstrained and their souls deadened by bitter struggle and want. These are the real poor of every community—the masses who, not lacking in industry and thrift, are yet never really able to earn enough for decent existence and who toil on in constant fear that bare necessities may fail." 4. The Minimum Standard of Life By the increase of human knowledge and the influence of the advance¬ ment of civilization, human wants gradually extend to include more than the things necessary for a bare existence, such as decency, comfort, and luxury. Each person, as a member of society, has to satisfy his want for decency in order to keep up his or her social position. We must, in other words, maintain a minimum standard "in keeping with the dignity of a human being."10 This mode and scale of activities, adjusted to' the wants for necessity and decency, will he termed the minimum standard of living, or simple Ufe standard. 5. The Efficiency Standard of Life Civilized man is not satisfied with the plane of decent living only. He desires to enjoy a certain scale of comfort which he considers indispensable 8. Parmelee: Poverty and Social Progress, p. 106. 9. J. H. Hollander:' The Abolition of Poverty, pp. 4-5. 10. J. A. Ryan: Living Wage, p. 72.

In life and which helps to keep him efficient. The mode and scale of activities, adjusted to his wants for necessity, decency, and comfort, will be termed the efficiency standard of living, or "Kulturleben" standard.11 This standard corresponds to that described by the National Industrial Conference Board as "the so-called standard of health and decency, which is one not yet generally found in Ithe families of unskilled laborers, but which h the goal toward which they are striving."12 To quote Cornish, he describes it as "the health and comfort standard" and adds "this plane of life provides not only for the material wants of man, such as food, shelter, and body covering, but also fo'r some comforts—clothing that is at onoe respectable and comfortable; insurance that takes care of the major misfortunes of life; and a degree of some education as well as amuse¬ ments."13 We must remember that "comfort is different from luxury. Comfort it always essential and important for efBciency because the satisfaction of the wants for comfort results in producing more efficiency, directly or indirectly. It may be necessary to devote a comparatively large sum of money to the securing of comfort, but the result of the expenditure will prove profitable by giving high vitality and great energy."14 This standard calls for the minimum amount of the requirements in a balanced diet with sufficient nutrition in terms of calories, proteins, fats, vitamins, etc. It also calls for the same sort of requirements in the case of housing, clothing and the other elements of living. It is to the level of this ideal standard that we are striving to raise up the actual standard, and we are sure that "gradually, by processes of education, advertising, and propaganda, new habits and custo'ms can be formed which square with the ideal standards."10 6. The Luxury Standard of Life There is what may be designated the luxury standard of living. It is the mode and scale of activities adjusted to the wants for luxury beside those of necessity, decency, and comfort. "Luxury, while variously defined, involves always the thought of great consumption of wealth for unessential pleasures."1(>; or, "luxury is altogether unessential superfluous wants.""17 It 11. Itn Japanese this standard of living corresponds to that of "Bunka-seikatsu." 12. National Industrial Conference Board: The Cost of Living in the United States-, 1914-1926, p. 26. 13. Cornish: The Standard of Living, pp. 63—64. 14. K. Morimoto: Standard of Living in Japan, p. 18. 15. Edie: Economics, Principles and Problems, p. 109. 16. F. A. Fetter: Principles of Economics, p. 385. 17. C. Gide: Prin<iples of Political Economy, p. 370.

should he excluded from the efficiency, or comfort, standard though many people like to indulge in luxury. Some scholars, such as Leroy Beaulieu and McCulloch, insist that luxurious expenditure is beneficial and that it is necessary for the advancement1 of social life. "To make men industrious —to make them shake off that lethargy which benumbs their faculties, even in a rude or depressed condition, they must be inspired wjth a taste for the comforts, luxuries, and enjoyments of civilised life."18 But I can never be an apologist for luxury. With Laveleye I stand as its opponent. The effect of luxury on the individual is to discourage the spirit of steadiness and sobriety, to cause lavish expenditures in family budgets, and to undermine health. Socially the effect of luxury is as follows: it decreases the wealth-producing power of the nation; it brings about higher prices for commodities; it increases the importation of foreign goods; and it disturbs social peace. 7. Rise in the Standard of Living Since the standard, of living is a certain condition of activities adjusted to wants, "a rise in the standard of life implies an increase of intelligence and energy and self-respect; leading to more care and judgment in expendi¬ ture and to an avoidance of food and drink that gratify the appetite but afford no' strength, and of the ways of living that are unwholesome physically and morally."19 Men strive hard to raise their* standard of living to the efficiency level and then they "will struggle much harder to prevent their standard's falling than they will struggle to raise it."20 A rise in the standard of life for the whole population brings about a corresponding increase of national prosperity and consequently an advancement of civilization, which will again in turn induce people to strive for a higher standard of living. Such being the case, rises in the standard of living and in the progress of civilization move forward hand in hand reacting alternately on onei another as cause and effect. 8. Population and the Standard of Living The standard of living has much to do with the theory of population. For the study of this subject there are at least two principles which must be observed. 18. McCulloch: Political Economy, p. 518. 19. A. Marshall: Principles of Economics, 1916, p. 689. 20. B. W. Knight & N. L. Smith: Economics, Vol. I. p. 380.

(i) Growth of population tends to keep the standard of living at the point of bare subsistence. This is a natural outcome of the Malthusian theory insisting that the potential increase of population is indefinitely greater than the power of producing food. The congestion of population and the prevalence of the pauper standard of living in oriental nations illustrate the validity of this principle. (2) Growth of population tends to be checked by the effort to raise the standard of living. One of the strongest motives for human activities is the desire to enjoy a higher standard of life. Many would rather sacrifice marriage and the procreation of children in order to maintain a high standard of living. Recently, the standard of living has been steadily rising because by the use of modern inventions and mass production prices have been reduced to such a point as to attract purchasers with even small incomes to buy com¬ modities and services formerly only within reach of the luxury class. The high standard, once maintained, will be tenaciously adhered to and relin¬ quished only with the utmost reluctance. In order to enjoy the comfort standard of life, civilized people will as a whole make sacrifices such as the postponement of marriage and the begetting of children. The birth-control movement and knowledge is disseminated principally among people of the upper classes. Eventually, "The desire to maintain and raise the standard of life is the most effective motive limiting population in our society."21 It has also heen said that "a high quality of population is in another sense a cause, and not merely an effect, of a high standard of consump¬ tion."" There are, at the present time, many countries influenced by the first principle and suffering from overpopulation and a low standard of living. There are also some countries influenced by the second principle and characterized by small families and a high standard of living. It is important to get a balanced ratio hetween population and the standard of living in harmony with the ever active process of social evolution. 21. Fetter: Econom'ic Principle, p. 4-18. 22. B. W. Knight & N. L. Smith: Economics, Vol. I. p. 271.

CHAPTER III FAMILY INCOME More and more attention, scientific and practical, is now being paid to the question,—What does it cost to live? In embarking on the study of this problem, it must be rememibered that the question is of a complicated nature, because it depends upon at least four things: first, "where to live"; second, "when to live"; third, "how to live," and fourth, "who to live." Relating to "where to live," the economic distance is daily becoming shortened by the rapid progress in means of transportation. The differences in the living cost in different localities are thus becoming year by year less conspicuous. The changeable nature of the living cost due to the influence of "when to live" is a well known fact, but it can, to a certain degree, be adjusted by the use of the index] num'bers of the cost of living which will be treated in Chapter V. For "how to live," we have divided the scales of living cost into four grades corresponding to the four different standards of living described in the previous chapter. The main purpose of this investigation is to find out the cost of maintaining the efficiency, or comfort, standard of living. This standard is, however somewhat theoretical and it must be ascertained by the deter¬ mination of the actual cost of family expenditures which is naturally con¬ trolled by the amount of the family income. With the progress of capitalistic civilization the influence of the family income is becoming not only more powerful but is, at present, the leading determinant of the living cost. Most of the estimates of family incomes in Japan which will be treated in this chapter are taken directly, or adapted, from the reports by the Bureau of Statistics.1 Considering the nature of the subject it must be admitted that such estimates can represent no more than approximations and such figures are useful only in explaining the general situation. The average national income in Japan in 1925, according to the calculation of the Bureau of Statistics, was ¥224 per capita and ¥1,124 per family. CHAPTER IV FAMILY EXPENDITURES - The previous chapters have revealed what is the actual status of family incomes in Japan. How these family incomes are consumed will now be analysed. The intelligent families nowadays control their expenditure of income by the use of. family budgets which consist of the designation of "the group :of commodities and services, for which prices are gathered, with their respective quantities of consumption or proportions in the total ex¬ penditure."1 Usually, the family budgets of working-class families are made the objects of study because it is almost impossible to get a clear notion of the representative expenditures of living unless the scales and modes of living are comparatively simple. As the items of family expenditure are so numerous it will be expedient to make a selection of the more representative items. "While great diversity of opinion exists as to what articles and services should be selected, the majority of authorities on the subject agree that the selections should, in some measure, represent the following five groups into which the main expenditures of an average household can be classified—(i) food, (2) housing, (3) fuel and light, (4) clothing, and (5) miscellaneous items."2 A number of analyses of family budgets have been made in different localities of Japan, but the methods of investigation are confusing. Only such studies as have been considered useful for this work have been selected, and their diverse items of expenditures have, to facilitate comparative discus¬ sions, been classified into five "major items." 1. National Industrial Conference Board: The Cost of Living in Foreign Countries, 1927, P. 9. 2. National Industrial Conference Board: The Cost of Living in Foreign Countries, p. 10.

As previously intimated the latest and most extensive study of family budgets so far made in Japan is the one carried out by the Bureau of Statistics, which investigated the expenditures of 5,455 families during 1926-1927. It will be worth while to enter more fully into the details of this investigation. The percentage distribution of expenditures for the major items in the family budgets by income groups shows that Engel's Laws of Consumption are confirmed in a general way in Japan. To be more exact: I. The law that, "the greater the income the smaller the proportionate expenditure for food" is confirmed. In this proposition Engel goes still further, stating "The proportion expended for food is a sure index of the material prosperity of a people."3 2. That "the percentage of expenditure for clothing is approximately the same, whatever the income," is confirmed. 3. That "the percentage of expenditure for housing, and for fuel and light, is invariably the same, whatever the income," is not confirmed. 4. That "as the income increases in amount the percentage of expendi¬ ture for sundries becomes greater" is confirmed. 3. R. C. Chapin: Standard of Living among Workingmen's Families in New York City, pp. 11-12.

Percentage distribution of expenditures for the major items in the family budgets by classified occupations indicates, in general, the following tendencies, as shown in Table XIII: I. The percentage of expenditure for food is least in the salaried class, and greatest in the families of farmers, while that of the wage earners occupies an intermediate position. 2. The percentage of expenditure for housing among those of the salaried class is much greater than among either the wage earners or the farmers. 3. The percentage of expenditure for fuel and light is the greatest in the farmers' class and almost identical in both the salaried and the wage earners' classes. 4. The percentage of expenditure for both clothing and sundries is greatest in the salaried class, and the least in that of the farmers. Table XIV which is a comparison of three different professional classes —"government officials," "bankers and employees of companies" and "teachers," reveals great differences in the percentage distribution of expendi¬ tures in the family budgets for major items other than clothing. While "bankers and employees of companies" spend. \^\% for clothing, teachers spend only 12.78%. This would seem to indicate a relatively well-dressed appearance in favor of the business men! Allowing for the fact that land-owning-farmers may be presumed to have larger incomes than tenant farmers, it is found that they are no exception to the general laws of consumption described on page 20 and as shown in Table XV. In "Sundries" there are, as far as the amount of expenditures is con¬ cerned, three important items; I. "Society," which includes parties, presents, etc., amounting to ¥10.29; 2. "Health," amounting ¥7.68; 3. "Pleas¬ ures," amounting to ¥6.03. These figures appertain to the salaried class. They are much greater than those of wage earners and farmers. The fact that the farmers spend so much as ¥7.58 fo'r "Society" while spending only ¥2.71 for "Health" and ¥2.16 for "Pleasures" indicates the sturdy survival in rural districts of putting so much stress on ceremonial affairs while their brothers in the cities are year by year cutting down the expenditure on social observances.

CHAPTER V THE CHANGES IN THE COST OF LIVING (Computation of the Index Numbers of the Cost of Living in Japan, 1915-1930) The development of index numbers for the purpose of estimating and of comparing the relative changes in the cost of living is of somewhat recent origin. At the present time index numbers are compiled more or less regularly in most civilized countries including Great Britain, France, United States, Germany, Denmark, Belgium, Greece, Austria, Australia, Italy, Netherlands, Russia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, etc. In all a total of about forty countries keep statistics along this line. They are constructed mostly by some department of the" central government or of a municipal administration. In a few cases, they are compiled by non-official organiza¬ tions or even by individual efforts. It is very strange that index numbers of the cost of living have never yet been compiled in Japan. The latest publication on the subject states:1 "No index numbers of the cost of living, properly speaking, are compiled in Japan, although there are several series of unweighted index numbers of retail prices of daily necessities. The authors of these indexes, however, state that they are not intended to measure changes in the cost of living; hence any references to them as indexes of the cost of living, which are occasionally found, rest upon misapprehension." I was informed recently by the authorities of both the Department of Commerce and Industry, and of the Bureau of Statistics that they have little hope of obtaining a sufficient appropriation to carry out the work of constructing index numbers of the co'st of living in the near future. Under the circumstances, therefore, there has been no alternative but to compile my own index numbers of the cost of living. I am fully conscious that such work is almost beyond the capacity of a single individual, but in connection with my researches in other direc¬ tions, it is essential that I should have such figures notwithstanding the fact that they may not be quite complete. The basis of the study is the investigation of the family budgets of 1,575 salaried employees', 3,210 wage earners' and 670 farmers' families during one year from September, 1926 to August, 1927 by the Bureau of 1. The results of my computations are given in Table XVII and in Chart I. Since the beginning of the twentieth century the standard of living has been steadily rising, and from the time of the World War, the cost of living, especially in Japan, has made rapid advances. The index number indicates that it rose to the highest1 point in 1919, namely to 317.29, based on 100 in 1914. It then began gradually to fall, and from 1929 up to the present time the rate of falling has been much accelerated. As a result of the rapid increase in the cost of living and the advance¬ ment of the economic society in Japan the rise in the standard of living has been very conspicuous. As stated elsewhere, it is the nature of human beings to strive hard to raise higher and higher the standard of living, and once a certain level has been attained they will again strive even harder to prevent it from dropping below that level. In comparing the index numbers of Japan and foreign countries, we find that the rising rate in Japan since 1914, was much greater than in the United States, Great Britain and several other countries. The reason for this is that, although the index numbers of the cost of living in' the basic year of 1914 are naturally the same in those countrie.s, the actual cost and standard of living are quite different; but countries like Japan and Italy, on account of their cost of living having been relatively low, had much more scope for increasing to reach the level of the more advanced countries. Then again in descending, due chiefly to the recent economic depression, the people have striven much harder not to let the standard of living fall with the lower cost of living. The depression however, became still more severe during the last year or so. In October, 1930, the cost of living went down as low as 144.19—and it seems that it may even drop to the level of 1914 if the economic conditions should remain as bad as they are. The standard of living cannot, however, be lowered so much as the living cost. On the contrary, the low prices,may actually help keep up the standard to a considerable degree. Thus, the relation between the cost and the standard of living is very close, but they are not similar at all. Naturally the index number of the cost of living would not be the sole measure of the standard of living.

CHAPTER VI THE NATIONAL DIET OF JAPAN To ascertain the food requirements of an average standard of living in Japan, the national diet is to he studied by the use of an extensive method of investigation. The national diet, which means the average diet of a nation, is obtained by dividing the total amount of the food destined for the consumption of the nation by the number of the total population reduced to the equivalent number of the adult population. One should remember that food consumption is a matter which differs according to different individuals, localities, climates, customs, and manners. Such being the case, the intensive method of investigation based upon the data of limited numbers often results in an erroneous conclusion with regard to the actual status of the national diet as a whole. The first step of this method is to find out the total amount of the food produced in the year to be investigated; the next, to add all imports of food; the third, to subtract all exports and also such parts of food produce which will be not used for food; and the fourth, to divide the1 sum by the number of the total population reduced to the equivalent of adults. For the sake of convenience, the regular scale of equivalent1 has been reduced to the following simplified scale: A man or woman over 15.................. 1.0 A child of 10-15 ........................ 0.8 A child of 5-10 ........................ 0.6 A child under 5 ......................... 0.4 By the adoption of these equivalents, the total population of 62,938,200^ is equivalent to 53,375,999 adults. In dividing the total net amount of the yearly produce of food by the adult , population, the quotient is the amount of the national diet per capita per annum. The national diet obtained in such a way necessarily cannot be very exact; but the results are very suggestive and valuable in the study of the national standard of living, provided we consider them in coordination with the results of the intensive studies of food consumption. 1.0 A boy of 15-16.. 0.8 A girl of 15-16 A boy of 13-14____ 0.8 A girl of 13-14. 0.7 A boy of 10-11. i. Consumption of Grains The most important grain in Japan is rice. The first use of rice is as the principal food item. Generally speaking, the principal food in Japan is exclusively composed of polished rice. Every day plain boiled rice without milk or sugar, in such a large quantity as about three bowls, on an average, is consumed at each o'f the three meals.3 The second use is in the brewing of the national strong drink called sake. The third is for manifold purposes, such as the making of confectionery, starch, and barm (koji). Also seed for the next year's crop is stored away. The second and the third uses, however, are minor compared with the first. To be more exact, 1.095 koku (5.07 bushels) per annum, or 3 go (450 grams) peri diem is the average amount of rice consumption. The general belief that the Japanese principal food consists entirely of rice is true of the urban population only. The rural population use naked barley and other grains mixed and boiled with rice for their principal food. The poorer the farmer, the greater proportion of grains other than rice is used. The consumption of naked barley is 0.55 bushels per capita per annum. Ordinary barley and wheat are cultivated in Japan, but the former is chiefly used for making beer and feeding horses, and the latter for making flour. The Japanese consume more vegetables than any other people in the world, and there are two most important kinds, namely, sweet-potatoes and daikon (garden radishes). The daily average consumption of sweet-potatoes and daikon are 131 grams and 124 grams respectively. The total of these two, amounting to 255 grams, consists of 53% of the total consumption of vegetables which is 476 grams in all. Such an enormous consumption of sweet-potatoes is due to the fact that they are used in the southern part of Japan as a part of the daily principal food and also as a kind of sweet eaten between regular meals. Garden-radishes are most extensively used as pickles which are known by the name of takuwan-zuke. They are prepared by being first dried and then pickled in a mixture of rice bran and plenty of salt. Consumption of Legumes The soy bean (soja bean, daizu), which is very rich in proteins and fats, is the most essential legume in Japan. It is a good substitute for meat, though its nutritive value, especially in its digestibility and its vitamin contents may be inferior to meat. In comparison with its market value, however, the nutritive value is very high. The essential element of the most common dishes in daily use, such as miso, shoyu, and tofu, is the soy bean, and the numerous soy bean recipes are the favorite relishes of the people.

Consumption of Fruits Generally speaking, fruits are consumed by most Japanese as a refresh¬ ment between meals, and have little value as a regular food-stuff. One exception, however, is plums (ume); the quantity of the consumption of plums is not so large as oranges and persimmons, 'but it is the only kind o'f fruit which is consumed as regular food-stuff. This preparation is called umeboshi which is made by first drying the fruit and then pickling in plenty of salt. As a consequence of its being inexpensive and appetizing, it is consumed extensively throughout the country especially among the poorer classes of people. The umeboshi and pickled radish (takuwan-zuke) are unexcelled as appetizers, giving a relish that otherwise would he lacking in the plain boiled rice. Consumption of Animal Food In Japan, animal protein, which is the most important nutrient, is chiefly obtained from fish. More than four hundred kinds of fish are caught in Japanese waters and they are consumed by the Japanese in the same way as meat is used by the Americans. The total consumption per capita per diem is 65 grams. The price of fish is much cheaper than meat and the cost of fish consumption per capita per diem is only 2.2 sen. Besides fish, shell-fish is a popular food in Japan but it is minor in comparison with fish. The habit of eating meat is not very old in Japan. Formerly some of the Buddhists were forbidden to eat animal food of any kind and only the outcast class could enjoy animal meat. This has now changed but still the consumption of meat is limited to only a certain class of people though it is increasing steadily year by year. Consumption of Sugar and Salt In order to make the most of the nutrients contained in food, it is necessary to have good cooking with proper seasoning. Sugar and salt serve as most important elements in seasoning. Sugar is important not only as a nurient but also as an indispensable condiment. One may probably relate the consumption of sugar to the progress of civilization. A growing use of sugar seems to indicate a growing civilization. Owing to a heavy protective tariff in the interests of native sugar, the price of sugar in Japan is scarcely exceeded anywhere in civilized countries. This fact is naturally a barrier to' the free use of sugar. In Japan as a whole, sugar is used most commonly for confectionery, and is not yet in much demand for cooking purposes as it ought be. In the poorer rural districts sugar is not used at all except a very little in the form of sweets,7 The consumption of salt is great partly from the fact that the habitual taste of the majority of the Japanese is inclined to salt. Such national food articles as shoyu, miso, tsukemono, which are used everywhere in great quantities for almost every meal, have plenty of salt for their essential ingredient. The sale of salt is a government monopoly in Japan and its price is not so low as it should be. CHAPTER VII THE TREND OF CHANGES IN THE NATIONAL DIET By the use of the same method of investigation, I have been keeping up the study of the national diet so far in five different years, namely, 1916, 1918, 1921, 1925, and 1929. In comparing these studies, it is interesting to discover that some changes with a certain regularity are occurring from time ta time in the consumption of food materials in Japan at large. To state some of the striking features: in grains, there is a tendency toward a gradual decrease of consumption in the grains other than rice. This is because the standard of living of the rural population has recently risen to a higher level and now they use more rice and less other grains as their principal food. In vegetables, we notice the great decrease of sweet-potato consump¬ tion. This also may be due to the fact that those people in the southern part of Japan who used to eat sweet-potatoes as their principal food are now consuming more rice as do their brothers in the urban districts. There is a noteworthy increase of consumption in all kinds of fruits. Then, a steady and gradual increase of consumption in meat and milk is conspicuous. The consumption of sugar has been invariable since 1918, but the use of salt has greatly increased. Sake consumption increased rapidly up to 1921 and then greatly dropped. Beer, though the amount of consumption is very little compared to that of sake, shows a gradual increase in its use. In the consumption of tobacco, the use of cigarettes is increasing and kizami (chopped) has decreased. The consumption of tea has been the same at all periods, probably always approximating the point of saturation from the olden time up to this date. CHAPTER VIII FOOD FOR THE EFFICIENCY STANDARD OF LIVING Rational food consumption should be controlled by the following factors: (i) Amount of Nutrients, (2) Amount of heat generation, (3) Absorption and digestibility, and (4) Market price of food. Besides the adequate vitamin contents, protein, fat and carbohydrate are the three forms of nutrients which should be contained in food. The most valuable form of these three from the standpoint of economy and physiology is protein, because it is the most expensive nutrient in price and its function especially that of animal protein, is more essential than other nutrients. There are differences of opinion as to the amount of nutrients needed pei' capita per diem. According to the most commonly recognized authorities, such as Voit, Atwater, Playfair, etc., we may set a standard of daily dietaries for an average Japanese at moderate work as follows: Protein, 96 grams; fats, 45 grams; carbohydrates, 406 grams.1 These figures were formerly modified in consideration of the Japanese dietary habit of not using so much animal food as the Westerners, and the Bureau of Hygiene of the Japanese Government arranged the standard in 1886 as follows: Protein, 96 grams; fat, 20 grams; and carbohydrates, 450 grams.2 The dietary habits of the Japanese, however, have greatly changed since that time and nowadays at least the younger population craves for meals containing twice as much of fats as what is supposed to be adequate according to the old standard suggested by the Bureau of Hygiene. While one gram of either protein or carbohydrate produces 4.1 calories, fat generates as much as 9.3 calories. The amount of calories required by the average Japanese, body-weight being 52 kilograms, is about 2,400 calories. This figure includes about 200 calories for food waste and about 140 calories for the heat needed for digestion and absorption. Unless the nutrients are easily digested and absorbed, the heat requirement will be greater. For this reason especially, though vegetable protein is much cheaper in price than animal protein, the former is as a nutrient inferior to the latter on account of the fact that it is less digestible and will not absorb easily. CHAPTER IX IMPROVEMENT OF FOOD CONSUMPTION IN JAPAN To maintain an efficiency standard of living, the right use of food is fundamentally necessary. Recent progress in the scientific study of nutrition and cookery, however, has been too rapid to keep pace with the dietary habits of the great mass of the poor people. Naturally, there are a number of defects in the Japanese habits of food consumption and the following may be suggested for their improvement: i. Increase in the consumption of animal protein AND VITAMIN As far as the amount of calories is concerned, the Japanese diet is not insufficient, but the quality of the source from which the calories generate is not quite adequate. First of, all, there is a lack of animal protein and vitamins. Fishes which are abundant in supply and comparatively low in price should be consumed in larger quantities by the rural population. Animal protein is of course much more expensive, but when realizing the happy result of better health and hence greater efficiency of labor which it brings, consuming meat in generous quantities will be profitable. The urgent need for the improvement of the Japanese dietary habit is to increase the consump¬ tion of meat, milk and dairy products which are the essential source of vitamins. For this purpose, a much lower price is necessary in order that the great mass of people may be accommodated. 2. Increase in the consumption of leguminous food; The nutritive value of plant-protein is not so large when compared to that of animal protein, but their prices, being rather low, are within reach of the purchasing power of the average person. By the greater use of legumes, the deficiency of animal protein may be supplemented to a certain degree. 3. A Less Quantity of Rice and a Greater Variety of Vegetables and Other Subordinate Food The common diet among the mass of the poor people in Japan as a whole consists of boiled rice, soya-bean soup (Misojiru), and pickled garden radishes. Both soy-bean and the pickled radish act as good appetizers on the

plain boiled rice. Such simple food is very cheap in cost, but this advantage is apt to be offset by the danger of malnutrition due to the enormous use of rice as a main food. The amount of the daily consumption of rice must be lessened by using a more varied supply of other kinds of grains and vegetables, especially such things as wheat, corn, and potatoes. The disadvantage of a diet which is composed of too much rice and too little subordinate food is twofold: first, it is hard to get nutrients in sufficient quantity; second, when a varied diet is obtainable, the intensity of the appetite is so great as to cause one to eat more than is physiologically needed. In order that food may havoi its proper variety, too much salt should not be used in its preparation. Vitamins and other nutrients can be properly and advantageously absorbed only when food of proper variety is consumed. 4. Less use of refreshments between meals The under-consumption of regular meals and the over-consumption of refreshments between meals have cyclical relations to each other. Japanese custom compels the excessive use of tea, sweets, fruits, etc. at irregular times. For example, it is common etiquette to serve tea and sweets to visitors, no matter what the purpose or the time of the call may be. As may be expected, the use of refreshments naturally weakens the appetite for regular meals, which in turn promotes the desire for refreshments. Such cyclical relations cause malnutrition an the long run. It is mo're enjoyable, as well as more economical, to concentrate the pleasing sensations which come from food consumption. In the case of children and certain persons for whom some supplementary food is necessary, the additional meals should be provided at regular intervals. 5. Improvement of the kitchen A more careful attention should be paid to the construction of the kitchen. The customary idea that the "guest room" is the most important is erroneous. The kitchen and living rooms which are in constant use must be given preeminence in location and construction. Then primitive stoves and utensils in common use must be improved to save the waste of time and labor.

CHAPTER X CLOTHING FOR THE EFFICIENCY STANDARD OF LIVING The study of clothing from the view of economic consumption is a subject exceedingly complicated because it changes greatly according to the taste, income, fashions, climate, social classes, etc. Naturally, there ar" as yet only a few publications which are available for the study of clothing in Japan. My work on this line of study dealing with clothing is based on the data of 1914—15.1 Due to the scarcity of more recent investigations and also to the fact that on the whole the use of clothing and its expenditure has not changed much since that time, I herewith use the same data, only with changes in price, to ascertain the proper clothing adequate for the efficiency standard of living in the large cities of Japan. The figures are the average of seven hundred and forty-three schedules, and those enumerated here are the average for Tokyo, Nagoya, and Kyoto. Cost per annum Dressmaking .......................... 12.55 Needles, threads ....................... 1.75 Other articles ......................... 16.65 Total ........................... ill .40 Each adult ........................... 37.13 Each child ........................... 12.38 The leading features of the expenditure for clothing in the Japanese cities are as follows: (1) The fabric most used is cotton; the consumption of cotton fabrics per capita per annum is 31 yards, entailing an expenditure of about three yen. (2) The materials next in importance are silk fabrics and silk mixtures. The consumption per capita per annum is 6 yards, an expense of three yen. (3) Woolen fabrics and woolen mixtures are used only to a small extent; their consumption per capita per annum is 1.2 yards, a value of eighty-eight sen. The use of these fabrics is generally limited to the urban population. (4) The expenditure for clothing is greater in the large cities than in the small ones. (5) The percentage of expenditure for clothing decreases with the increase of income. (6) In the apportionment of expenditure for clothing among the different members of the family, the father uses 54%, the mother 38%, the girl 18%, and the boy 12%. (7) The use of European clothing is limited chiefly to the father and the children. The use of European clothing results as whole in a greater expenditure for clothing on the father's part, but for the children it frequently means some saving in cost over their native clothing. (8) The Japanese dress varies greatly in style, form and material. At least three different kinds of both overcoats and garments (padded, medium weight, and light weight) must be provided according to the change of the seasons. (9) The costly Japanese costume can be worn for a comparatively long time. Generally, silk costumes which are worn by the majority of people are not so durable, but since they are worn on only a few special occasions, probably not mo're than one or two dozen times a year among people of the middle classes, they may last over a period of ten years or more. For this reason, the yearly expenditure for clothing is not so heavy in spite of its high price.

CHAPTER XI IMPROVEMENT OF CLOTHING Recently men and children have come) to use European costume to a great extent. European clothing is necessarily worn as the street and work¬ ing dress, and the Japanese, as the house and ceremonial dress. It would be a convenient custom to adopt both the Japanese and European dress if it v/ere not necessary to: consider the expense. The. expense of two kinds of clothing, howver, is so'mewhat of a waste and can hardly be justified in an efficiency standard of living. For the improvement of clothing, the use of only one set, either European or Japanese, is fundamentally necessary. As for (women's apparel, however, the use of the European costume is limited to a very small number. In comparing European and Japanese clothing, the following points should be observed: (i) The Japanese dress is not serviceable for active work. (2) The making of the Japanese dress requires a greater expenditure of time] and labor than that of the European garment. (3) The main materials used for the Japanese dress^—namely, silk and cotton—are not so satisfactory as wool, which is the main material used for the European dress. On the other hand,, the Japanese costume has the following points which surpass the European: (1) The European dress fits too tightly and is not so comfortable as tha Japanese dress, especially for those who are unaccustomed to the European kind. (2) Making men's European clothes at home is generally impracti¬ cable. (3) Mending European clothes is very difficult, while the Japanese dress ,is very easily mended and is co'mmonly remade. Taking all these factors into consideration, there is a tendency for the European costume1 to possibly become an integral part of the native dress in Japan, at least for men and children. ' Asj for women, however, the use of European clothes is almo'st insignificant. The reasons why Japanese women do not adopt the European clothes may be enumerated as follows: (1) Japanese women, generally speaking, have! comparatively short legs in proportion to' the rest; of the body, and on them, the Japanese dress (2) In the moral training of Japanese women even at present, great

stress is placed on the virtues of gentleness and meekness even sacrificing modern conveniences. (3) The Japanese women as a whole are not required to enter such an active life as men, and the inconveniency in wearing Japanese costume is not so great as with men. (4) For the sake of economy, women keep to the use of one set of Japanese clothing only. The fashions o'f the European dress change much oftener and it would be quite expensive to follow those ever-changing fashions. Taking the foregoing points into consideration, the Simplification and the Economy of Clothing are of the first importance for improvement. Japanese custom tends to lavishness and waste in expenditure for clothing. Too many different kinds of suits are required to appear properly on different occasions. First, three different kinds of garment in weight—"wataire," "awase," and "hitoye"—in both kimono (coat) and haori (overcoat)— are used for the different seasons. Then the garments for each season must include an everyday dress, a visiting dress, and a ceremonial dress. The ceremonial dress and the visiting dress are very costly but their use is greatly limited. They are simply hoarded and are often used as little as once or twice a year. Under the circumstances, a lavish custom, such as to make women feel it is necessary to change her visiting dress at each social call in order to display her large store of clothing, is still prevailing :n ladies' society. In the improvement of women's clothing, however, we must not slight the importance of grace and beauty in dress. Since the idea of ornament is one of the important objects of clothing, simplification or practicability should not impair graceful and beautiful lines. At the same time, freedom of movement and reasonable durability of material should be maintained in the Japanese costume. So far the so-called improved garment which has been proposed from time to time has been rather a failure. The chief reason has been that it has not combined aesthetic lines with its practical and economical nature. It is therefore desirable that specialists should design improved garments well adapted to Japanese conditions in order to maintain an efficient standard of life. Until then, it is advisable that the apparel of men and chldren should be principally European, and that of the women, Japanese, with such improvements as (1) more use of the "hakama" which is a kind of skirt to put over the kimono, (2) simplification of the Bash ("obi"), (3) the use of improved clogs or sandals, (4) more machine work instead of hand work in the process of making garments.

CHAPTER XII HOUSING FOR THE EFFICIENCY STANDARD OF LIVING AND ITS IMPROVEMENT During the last decade or two, a number of new style houses have been built and housing conditions seem to have made a great change. On the whole, however, such changes in buildings have occurred only in very limited localities, mostly in the large cities. The housing conditions in Japan which I published in "The Standard of Living in Japan" will not be very far from the present housing conditions in the. rural districts. Out of the 863 schedules which were used in my former study1 in the survey for both clothing and housing in the cities, 680 have been used for this .study. Some of the leading facts as to housing conditions for the middle class, which is supposed to maintain the efficiency standard of living in the large cities, are as follows: A typical family of the income,) group of 960—1679 yen lives in a house of 1,504 square feet in the small cities and of 1,058 square feet in the large cities. The numher of rooms is about seven in both cases. The size of rooms is 115 square feet in the small cities and 90J square feet in the large cities. The 1930 rate of house rent is ¥13.46 in the small cities and ¥23.39 *n tne large 'cities. This fact means that about 20%> of the fanrly income is spent for rent in the large cities. The principles of expenditure for housing which are deduced as a result of the investigation are as follows: (1) The expenditure for housing in the family budget increases with the severity of the climate. (2) The expenditure for food, clothing, and housing stand in cor¬ relation in the family budget. (3) The expenditure for housing tends to increase rapidly as the family income increases. (4) The expenditure for housing in the family budget is much greater in the city than in the country; also, the larger the city, the greater the expenditure. (5) The rate of rent per month paid by poor families is greater than that by families of the middle and high classes. For the maintenance of the efficiency standard of living, the following conditions must be provided so' that the proper functions of a house may be fulfilled: 1. Morimoto: Standard of Living in Japan, pp. 115—126|.

(i) The house should be strong and large enough to accommodate the family comfortably and efficiently. (2) The house should have ample hygienic facilities such as good water supply, plenty of sunlight, good ventilation, sanitary disposal of waste materials, etc. (3) The building plan should be adapted to meet the needs of eco¬ nomic and social life. .,(4) The house should be located in a place both healthful and convenient. Just as there are minimum standards for food and clothing, so, also must there be a lower limit in the use of housing. Of course, that limit is very hard to ascertain and the only fundamental way to determine it is to work with the results of physiological experiments on the space necessary for human living. It is calculated that a man inspires from 16 to 18 cubic feet of air in an hour, and at the same time expires from 0.5 to 0.7 cubic feet of carbonic acid gas. Air which contains more than six ten-thousandths of carbonic acid gas is injurious to life. Based upon these figures, the minimum space which is physiologically necessary for one man has been estimated at 600 cubic feet for an ordinary living room, 1,000 cubic feet for dormitories or other buildings designed for group life, and 1,300 cubic feet for hospitals or other buildings where fresh air is especially needed. The rooms most commonly used in Japan are the six-mat room, which is 9 by 12 feet, or 108 square feet, and the eight-mat room, which is 12 by 12 feet, or 144 square feet. The usual height of the ceiling from the floor is 8^2 feet. Thus a six-mat room, which has a spatial area of 918 cubic feet, is large enough for one and a half adult persons, and an eight- mat room, which contains 1214 cubic feet, is large enough for two grown¬ ups. This means that 72 square feet of floor space are necessary for one person's sleeping place. In the ordinary Japanese house, the room area is about fifty per cent of the whole house area. According to this calculation, the necessary house area for an adult is 144 square feet and for a family of four adult members, 576 square feet. For the improvement of Japanese housing, the following suggestions may be made: (1) The united type, not the mixed one of Japanese and European types of building, should be adopted. Instead of putting European and Japanese types together side by side without much consideration of cost and harmony of architecture, the harmonious union of the Japanese and the European should be the main object of the improvement. (2) The European type of building, with much of Japanese art

taken in, should also !be encouraged. The Japanese type of building, which has grown out of the influence of ancient Korean, Indian, and Persian architectures, has a number of attractive features. This type, however, has certain points not suitable for modern life which is so oppressed by economic considerations. (3) It is desirable to abolish the use of tatami (straw-matting) because it is both unsanitary and uneconomical. Not only is it difficult to clean, but a change of the surface covering is necessary almost every year. (4) The building' plans should be so improved as to avoid a showy appearance without much practicability or utility. For example, thuogh the sitting room and kitchen are used constantly, they occupy a place much inferior to that of the parlor or the front vestibule, which are very little used. (5) The cooperative way of living should be encouraged. If rightly managed, the central heating system, cooperative kitchens and diniing rooms, such as in apartments and tenement houses, and the cooperative use of the yard, garden, bath, washing place, entrance, halls, corridors, and so on, would be beneficial for the maintenance of the efficiency standard of living for those having comparatively small family incomes,

CHAPTER XIII ESTIMATION OF THE COST OF LIVING FOR THE MAINTENANCE OF AN EFFICIENCY STANDARD OF LIVING IN JAPAN Something in the nature of a summary of the cost of living,- drawing together some of the foregoing 'factors, may properly be treated in these concluding pages. But the cost of living as previously stated, is condi¬ tioned by many different elements, and the computation of the expenditure cannot be done with a high degree of exactness unless a sufficient number of proper records can be obtained for similarly situated families. To obtain such records, however, is beyond the reach of my ability and these, studies only suggest some of the general ideas of the standard in the terms of family expenditure or income. Now then, what amount of family income should be necessary for the maintenance of an efficiency standard o'f living in Japan? For the computation of such cost, it is advantageous to adopt a method of estimation in deducing the total cost of living from the cost of food, clothing, and housing. According to Engel's Law of Consumption as stated before, the expenditure for food, does not grow in proportion to the total expendi¬ ture. "This decrease in the proportion of the income given to food went entirely to swell the expenditures on sundries."1 In order to enjoy there¬ fore a fair amo'unt of "sundries" which includes all expenditures for educa¬ tion, recreation, society, taxes, etc., the expenditure for food consumption must not exceed a certain limit. Now, the studies described in Chapter* VIII, show that the cost of the food consumption is 45.4 sen per capita per diem, o'r ¥1.50 per family of 3.3 units. On this basis, a family consisting of two grown-ups and three children, must spend about ¥45 per month for food. By the con¬ sideration of the percentage distribution o'f family expenditures as already stated, 35 % of the total cost of living is about the average of food expenditure for families sustaining the efficiency standard. Then, approximately, ¥130 will be the amount of family income with which an efficiency standard of living may be maintained in Tokyo. In the same way, the average clothing expenditure of a normal family is ¥18 per month corresponding to 14% of the total cost of living'; and 1. National Industrial Conference Board: "The Cost of Living in U. S. 1914—1927" p. IS.

the housing expenditure, ¥20, or 16%. On the basis of these percentages the total cost will amount to' ¥130 and ¥125' respectively. The deduction of the total cost of living from other items will bring about the same result. Such being the case, the conclusion is that a family income of ¥130 per month is the minimum amount required for the maintenance of an efficiency standard o'f living in the large cities. The amount and percentage distribution of the family expenditure may then be summarized as follows: TABLE XL MINIMUM FAMILY EXPENDITURE AND ITS DISTRIBUTION AS REQUIRED FOR THE MAINTENANCE OF AN EFFICIENCY STANDARD OF LIVING (Per family per month in 1931) Cost (yen) per cent Food ...................... 45.50 35 Clothing ................... 18.20 14 Housing ................... 22.10 17 Sundries ................... 44.20 34 Total................ 130.000 100 As a whole, a normal family consisting of parents and three children will not be able to maintain the efficiency standard of living with a monthly income o'f less than ¥130 in 1931 in the city of Tokyo. The presumable range of these incomes may be set forth as ¥130—200 per month, or ¥1,500—2,400 per year. Ordinarily, the standard of living falls into three broad divisions: that of the poor, of the middle class, and; of the rich. Although these teims are used without much scientific precisio'n, customary usage will justfy the following interpretation of the terms. The poor is the term used in a broad sense for all those who are in such an economic insufficiency as not to be able to satisfy their wants for necessity and decency. Professor Hollander defines it in the narrowed sense as: "midway between the modestly circum¬ stanced and the outright dependent are' the poor in the sense of the inade¬ quately fed, clad, and sheltered."2 The middle class is the term including all those families whose income, if expended in the most economical ways, allows them to enjoy the efficiency 2. J. H,. Hollander: "Abolition of Poverty," p, 2.

standard; in other words, the income which is sufficient to maintain the mode and scale of activities adjusted to the wants for comfort or efficiency besides those of necessity and decency, but with no allowance for luxury. The rich is the term including all those families receiving an income greater than that needed for the maintenance of the efficiency standard of living. The surplus is generally spent in luxury, saving, investment, or social betterment. The income' range of these three grades of standard in Tokyo may be set approximately as "less than ¥1,500" for the poor, ¥1,500— 2;40o" for the middle class or those maintaining the efficiency standard of living, and "¥2,000 and over" for the rich.

Tao Preliminary Paper Prepared for the Fourth Biennial Conference of the Institute of Pacific Relations to be held in Hangchow, from October 21st to November 4th, 1931. Published by CHINA INSTITUTE OF PACIFIC RELATIONS, SHANGHAI—CHINA

BIBLIOGRAPHY It is impossible to enumerate here all the references but the following in the English language may be mentioned as important studies. Quarterly Journal of Economics, Vol. XXXIII pp. 107-128. The Chinese Economic Monthly, Vol. Ill p.264, 1926 L. K. Tao: Livelihood in Peking, 1928, Peiping. F. C. H. Lee and T. Chin: Village Families in the Vicinity of Peiping, 1929, Peiping. J. L. Buck: Chinese Farm Economy, Chap. X. 1930, Shanghai. L. K.
