essay:div.essay:p: V THE POSSIBILITIES AND LIMITATIONS OF INTERNATIONAL COMPARI¬ SONS OF COST OF LIVING AND FAMILY BUDGETS Memorandum prepared by the International Labour Office, Geneva, for the Fourth Biennial Conference of the Institute of Pacific Relations to be held at Hangchow, October 2\st to November 4th, 1931. Published by THE INSTITUTE OF PACIFIC RELATIONS HONOLULU, HAWAII 1931

This memorandum is one of a series of papers prepared by the International Labour Office for the Institute of Pacific Relations and for presenta¬ tion at the Fourth Biennial Conference of the In¬ stitute to be held at Hangchow in October, 1931, In submitting this material the Institute itself does not assume responsibility for statements of facts or opinions contained in the text. These remain as much the personal expression of the author as would be the case if the communication were made orally.

THE POSSIBILITIES AND LIMITATIONS OF INTER¬ NATIONAL COMPARISONS OF COST OF LIVING AND FAMILY BUDGETS In all questions relating to the international regulation of labour conditions, the problem of the worker's standard of living forms an essential part. The International Labour Office has from the outset interested itself in this problem. In 1925 the Office convened an international Conference of Labour Statisticians which (among other things) discussed the methods of compiling cost of living index numbers, and in 1926 a further conference discussed the methods of conducting family budget enquiries.(1) The object of these conferences was to draw up principles and methods for the compilation of national statistics, which if adopted would render these more comparable among themselves; they take therefore no account of the difficulties introduced into the problem by differences in habits, traditions, climate, etc. between various countries and the resolutions of these conferences have been publish¬ ed in the International Labour Review. (2) In May 1931 the Office convened a conference (the fourth) of Labour Statisticfans to consider the question of comparing "real wages" internationally. These comparisons as hitherto carried out by the Office, have related primarily to the European countries, the United States and the British Dominions; no attempt has been made to compare the purchasing power of wages in countries with very different standards of living; thus countries such as India, China (!) Methods of Compiling Cost of Living Index Numbers. Studies and Reports, Series N, No. 6, and Methods of Conducting Family Budget Enquiries. Studies and Reports. Series N. No. 9. (2) See International Labour Review, July 1925 and January 1927.

and Japan have been excluded. Moreover, they cannot really be said to measure standards of living as they refer to wages during a certain period of time of an adult male only, and take no account of the earnings of other members of the family; the number of dependent children, or other similar circumstances. The conference mentioned above passed a number of resolutions upon the comparisons of wages and cost of living internationally.(3) The interest in international comparisons of conditions of workers between the countries of Europe and North America has now ex¬ tended to the Far East, and during the last few years, numerous studies have been made of the standard of living and of family budgets in China and Japan. The International Labour Office has taken great interest in these enquiries and has published in its Inter¬ national Labour Review an account of the most important enquiries of which it had knowledge.(4) As yet, however, the Office has issued no report upon this subject and there is room, therefore, for a survey of the possibilities and limitations of international comparisons, both of purchasing power of wages and family budget enquiries. In the following memorandum it has not been possible to deal with all the intricate questions of a theoretical and practical nature which are involved in a complete study of this question: problems of a technical character have been largely excluded as they have been dealt with partly in the two studies on methods referred to above, and partly are likely to form the subject of a future study by the Office on international or place comparisons of cost of living. But as the possibility of making useful international comparisons (3) The resolutions of the Conference have been published in the International Labour Revieiv, July 1931. (4) See International Labour Review; March 1931, pp. 388-397, The Japanese Family Budget Enquiry of 1926-1927 and April 1931, pp. 550-558 Some Recent Family Budget Enquiries in Shanghai.

is primarily dependent on a clear conception of the nature and limitations of the basic problems involved, it has seemed desirable to deal in the present memorandum with general questions of a fun¬ damental nature. I. MEASUREMENT and comparison of standard of living Generally the term "standard of living" would seem to imply the totality of goods and services entering into the consumption of a family or a group of families during a certain period of time at any given place or time. If a given family or class of people com¬ mands a large quantity and variety of goods and services, it is said to have a high standard; if the consumption is restricted to smaller quantities or simple qualities, it is said to have a low standard. But if it is desired to extend the use of the terms to cover several countries (or periods of time at long intervals in the same country) with a view to comparing the height of the standard of living in the various countries (or at different times) serious difficulties pre¬ sent themselves. A severe climate makes a greater demand on housing, fuel and light, and even food, than a mild one; the fact that, the purchasing power of wages and standard of consumption is higher in England than in Italy cannot be taken as prima facie evid¬ ence that real wages and the standard of living are higher in the former country. Climatic differences are not the only ones that hamper comparisons; political, social and economic conditions, tastes and ideals, show great variety as between different countries. To compare standards of living internationally (or between different epochs) it would be necessary to measure and add benefits derived from various kinds of commodities and services; and to arrive at the net satisfaction—which ultimately would be the only means by which "real" wages or "standard of living" can be rationally mea¬ sured or compared—it would also be necessary to reckon with disutili¬ ties and disabilities, whether they are caused by strain in working, social and political maladjustments,, unfavourable climate, or any similar circumstance.

It thus finally proves impossible to arrive at a satisfactory measurement of real wages and standards of living because subjective satisfaction, its definition and measurement, pre-supposes a scale of values, the determination of which lies at present outside the domain of science. The impossibility objectively to classify standards of living as "higher" or "lower" has not prevented comparisons being made in practice. For everyday purposes such comparisons may be useful if it is kept in mind that the results depend upon the scale of values that the investigator consciously or unconsciously has formed for himself, and that comparisons of this nature must be arbitrary and consequently open to national and political bias. Recognising the necessary limitations to the problems of mea¬ suring standards of living, two methods may at present be discerned by which—within certain limits—useful approximations may be ob¬ tained- The first method is to measure the purchasing power (in a certain aggregate of commodities and services) of wages, (or in¬ comes.) Wages constitute a chief element among the factors deter¬ mining the workers' standard of living. Between countries and period with fairly similar conditions of life, tastes and habits, "real wages" (or better still "real incomes") are likely to represent for practical purposes standards of living with a fair degree of use¬ fulness. The second method is to compare item for item the ele¬ ments entering into the working-class consumption in various coun¬ tries. The material is at hand in the various national family budet enquiries, which in addition to supplying weights for cost of living indexes, also give the most reliable picture we possess of the actua manner of living among the majority of the world's working population. II. COMPARISONS OF COST OF LIVING Calculation of real wages: The international comparison of purchasing power of wages or incomes depends essentially upon two distinct series of basic data; the level of nominal wages or incomes and the prices of the articles and services on which the

worker spends his income. These factors may be treated separately; it is only necessary for them to be co-ordinated in so far as they should relate to the same dates, the same localities and the same categories of persons. We must leave here altogether 4he question of obtaining comparable money wages and money incomes in the different countries(5), a technical problem, whose thratment would carry us too far in the present connection. In other words, we are con¬ sidering here only the problem of measuring the purchasing power of money wages and incomes which are considered as given. The actual co-ordination between series of wages and series of indices for cost of living involves only a simple division. As a background to the comparisons of cost of living between different places, how¬ ever, it may be useful to reconsider briefly the general scope of time comparisons of cost of living.(6) Time comparisons of cost of living: Especially when great fluc¬ tuations in the value of money are taking place, it is important to compare wages—not in money—but in a more stable unit of mea¬ surement, and cost of living index numbers are computed by collect¬ ing the retail prices of the chief articles of consumption at various dates. The prices of the different articles are weighted according to the importance of the various articles in the consumption generally of a working-class family. The use of the "budgets" as a basic unit of measurement, how¬ ever, suffers from certain limitations. The consumption of the workers is changing; articles entering into the budget at one time disappear, new articles enter and the importance of the remainder changes. It is impossible to price now the budget of worker's family living a very long time ago, or (which amounts to the same thing) <5) Reference should be made to the appended resolution by the fourth International Conference of Labour Statisticians upon the subject. <e) See Methods of Compiling Index Numbers of the Cost of Living (Studies and Reports, Series N, No. 6) and Reoort of the Second International Conference of Labour Statisticians. (Studies and Reports, Series B, No. 8).

to price a modern budget for a long time in the past; as habits of consumption and relative prices change; the cost of living index becomes more and more imperfect. If an old budget is modified, the basic unit of comparison is changed also and the index num¬ bers before and after the revision in the base are not strictly com¬ parable. This limitation in the scope of comparisons of the cost of living at various periods by means of index numbers can never be wholly overcome. The above-mentioned changes in consumption are often so slow and happen so gradually that the error introduced is confined within narrow limits, and for short periods of time it may be ignored when compared with the uncertainty introduced by the fluctuations in the level of prices. Nevertheless it is essential to remember that as soon as we want to compare cost of living at distant periods of time, we are confronted with this unavoidable limitation which has been well stated by Mr. Irving Fisher:"...............we cannot con¬ sistently compare far distant times and climes by means of averages or widely varying elements. Either we must give up the attempt or we must content ourselves with an artificially rigid system of weights which contradicts the facts''. (7) General characteristics of place comparisons of cost of living: It is evident that instead of comparing prices at two different times in the same place, it is possible to compare them at two different places at the same time(8). The difficulties in making interlocal comparisons are theoretically of exactly the same order as those encountered in making time comparisons; the changes, however, in habits, traditions, income, climate, etc. between various places are very great—corres¬ ponding in fact to very long periods of time. The problems introduc¬ ed by making place comparisons of cost of living are, if not new in principle, of much greater magnitude, since the differences between <7> The Making of Index Numbers, p. 247. <8> See in this connection Methods of Compiling Cost of Living Index Numbers, p. 7, footnote. International Labour Office Studies and Reports, Series N, No. 6'.)

a series of localities are usually greater than between a series of years. The great differences between various places makes it necessary, therefore, to develop a technique of comparison by which it is possible to deal with this kind of difficulty. Moreover, as the comparisons, to be really useful, should extend over several countries, difficulties of an administrative order arise. An international enquiry demands the co-operation of many national authorities and offers greater difficulties than a national comparison in applying uniform methods. Items to be included in Budgets: As was pointed out in the Office's Report on Methods of Compiling Cost of Living Index Num¬ bers, "the earliest attempts to measure changes in the cost of living were usually based on changes in the prices in a given locality of a comparatively few items of ordinary consumption, mainly of food, heating and lighting.....If the movements of the prices of the groups of commodities not included were similar to those of the groups chosen, no purpose would be served by extending the scope of the enquiry. There is, however, abundant evidence to show that the movements, for example, of food prices since 1914 have been very different from those of the prices of other commodities, and in consequence adjustment of wages by means of index numbers of food prices could hardly be expected to give satisfaction".(9) The above holds true-—mutatis mutandis—for place index numbers. It is known that the relative dearness of various groups of commodi¬ ties varies considerably between different places; it is thus evident that to compile a satisfactory place index number, prices of all im¬ portant items should be admitted into the comparison. However, it is in practice difficult to enlarge the framework of the comparison. It may be easy to obtain price quotations regularly for certain staple qualities of food, fuel, etc. per kg-, litre or dozen. To get quota¬ tions for rent is at once more difficult; a "room" does not mean the same thing in all localities. Great local variations exist in the (9> loc. cit. p. 9.

qualities of articles of clothing; the obstacles in selecting and pricing items of "cultural" expenditure and personal services are still greater. The International Labour Office has always considered that satis¬ factory compilation of data can be secured only on the basis of close international co-operation. Enquiries regarding qualities and kind of commodities and services to be included in the budgets would best be conducted on the spot by means of personal visits to the different countries. Such procedure becomes the more necessary if—as recommended by the fourth international Conference of Labour Statisticians—the basis of comparison should contain in addition to prices on food, also particulars on fuel and light and housing.(]0) Methods of compiling budgets: In the previously mentioned study by the International Labour Office upon the compiling of index numbers, distinction is made between three methods of compiling the budgets: the aggregate expenditure method, the standard budget method, and the theoretical budget method. In making place com¬ parisons, it is theoretically possible to use any one or a combination of these methods. It is not necessary to repeat here reasons for and against them. It must be remarked, however, that in the present state of international statistics it is necessary to take refuge to a large extent in arbitrarily prepared budgets. The statistical material is as yet too scarce to allow the application of standard budgets for suffi¬ ciently large areas. Another question is that in constructing inter¬ national budgets, existing family budget enquiries and national cost of living indices, form the necessary groundwork. Basis of comparison: Comparisons of cost of living may be calculated on a "fixed" or a "chain" basis. The former system is <10> Partly owing to experiences acquired in the course of the "Ford en¬ quiry" which is at present being carried on by the Office it was deemed inadvisable to include also expenditure on clothing and mis¬ cellaneous items.

employed in compiling practically all national "time" index numbers, owing, no doubt, largely to its simplicity and ease of handling. The latter system has so far won little ground in practical statistics. These two systems are here examined from the point of view of compiling "place" index numbers of cost of living. Fixed base system: By the fixed base system of comparing cost of living, the same budget of commodities and services is priced in all the localities concerned. A form of such comparison is some¬ times carried out within the same country; the budgets used in com¬ piling national index numbers of cost of living are priced in various localities. To be of value, the localites should have fairly homo¬ geneous conditions of living. In other words, the comparison should not be extended over a greater area than that for which the national budget offers an adequate expression of habits of consumption. It would perhaps be possible to measure the cost of living in Scandinavian towns upon a budget from any of the three countries of Denmark. Norway and Sweden: it would not be adequate to use a single national budget in comparing the cost of living in Copenhagen and in London. It is necessary to take into account the conditions of consumption prevailing in London and in Copenhagen. Comparisons taking into account the conditions in all the localities concerned may be under¬ taken by means of different methods. The most obvious way to account for national differences is perhaps to calculate the cost of living on the basis of several regional budgets.(n) This method was employed by the International Labour Office before 1929. The cost of six regional budgets of foodstuffs was calculated in each of the towns included in the enquiry; the result, consequently, was six index numbers of cost of living for each town. To arrive at a unified and simple expression of the relative cost of living, these six indices were averaged; the result being an inter- (ID Throughout this memorandum the word "regional" is used in the sense of a group of countries having similar habits and customs.

national cost of living index number, which to a certain extent, took into account the particular food habits in various parts of the world. From a purely practical point of view, this system suffered from being cumbersome in handling. The compilation of six series of indices for each town and then averaging them, involved a great amount of labour. This work may be greatly decreased and account still taken of the consumption habits in each country—by averaging the budgets (the weights) instead of the final ratios (the indices). In fact it has been demonstrated experimentally that practical results reached by this method are almost the same as by the former method. (12> For this reason from 1929 to 1931 the International Labour Office made its computations on a single "international" budget obtained by aggre¬ gating the regional budgets instead of computing six different indices and taking the average. The Fourth International Conference of Labour Statisticians did not take definite sides as to which of the above methods is preferable and resolved only that: "Allowance should be made for the difference in articles consumed in each of the countries by basing the calculations successively on the list of important articles •••.consumed in the others". All comparisons of cost of living of this nature, however, are subject to certain limita¬ tions and it was pointed out by the Conference that they "cannot be usefully made between countries of widely differing customs and habits". This is to say that when in two or more countries the field of common consumption is a small one (or with another terminology; "the common factor" is low),<18> comparisons are apt to be uncertain. The International Labour Office has always recognised this limitation and has never attempted to include in its enquiry regions with con¬ ditions as different from modern Western industrial standards as, for instance, the Far-Eastern countries. A general treatment of this problem is given by Irving Fisher in his Making of Index Numbers (see specially chapter VIII, pp. 184-196). See for instance, J. M. Keynes, A Treatise on Money, Vol. I, pp. 105-109.

In actual practice, however, it is more rarely desired to compare the standard, of living in China with Great Britain or Argentina— comparisons which, on account of the great differences in habits hardly can be worth while—but rather with countries and districts of similar conditions: China with Japan or Korea, or perhaps with India; the North of China with the South of China, industrial districts with less industrialised areas; and so on. According to this view, the fourth International Conference passed a resolution that the cal¬ culation of place index numbers of cost of living "should be made not only as hitherto on a fixed international budget, but also on the basis of various national or regional budgets". Thus, comparisons between countries situated in the same region could be made on a fixed budget, being a composite of the various national budgets in this region; a comparison between countries situated in different regions—if practical—could be made on a fixed budget being a com¬ posite of the relevant regional budgets, and so on. It was pointed out in the introduction that the information on consumption habits in the Far East is rapidly accumulating as a con¬ sequence of the vivid interest, both public and individual, shown in conducting family budget enquiries. It would seem therefore as if it now would be possible to establish comparisons of cost of living between various countries and localities in a Far Eastern region. Which countries and classes of people should be included and in what detail the comparison should be carried out is a practical question that cannot be answered here. "Chain" base system : It is useful to take into account also the "chain" base system as a means of comparing cost of living in places with widely differing conditions of life by progressing from the similar to the dissimilar through places with intermediate conditions.(14) (14) F0ir a more technical description of the "chain" system, reference is made to Irving Fisher The Making of Index Numbers, pp. 18-22; and for a critical analysis to J. M. Keynes, A Treatise on Money, VoL I. pp. 116-120. Mr. Keynes, however, overlooks some impoi'tant aspects of the problem and especially the difficulties which arise in deter¬ mining' the "similarity" of various localities. See below.

It is sometimes believed that this system gives more satisfactory results than a system of direct comparison. However attractive the method may seem, it is nevertheless subject to very important limitations, both practical and theoretical. In recognition of these limitations the fourth Conference of Labour Satisticians passed the following resolution: "The Conference is unable to recommend the proposal to com¬ pare countries of dissimilar conditions by progression through coun¬ tries with intermediate conditions owing to the lack of information on such conditions at the present time and to the absence of any criterion for measuring the degree of dissimilarity among the intermediate countries." III. FURTHER COMPARISONS OF REAL INCOME AND STANDARD OF LIVING The Second International Conference of Labour Statisticians held in Geneva in 1925 expressed the opinion that, since the figures of real wages based on rates of wages of adult male workers "cannot be considered as represenative of the real differences in the workers' standard of living which exist from country to country, it is desirable that a second series of index numbers should be published along with the first, measuring the relative standard of living of the working classes in the different countries. In this case it would be class families and take account of the difference in the physiological reeds of the population, due chiefly to climate and race". It has, to the knowledge of the Office, never actually been attempt¬ ed to compare standards of living in the above manner. Theoretically the problem is of the same order as that of comparing real wages. Since it is impossible to measure the total satisfaction of populations, it would be necessary to find a standard of comparing the purchasing power of the total incomes of the families concerned. This involves problems of a highly technical order, which as yet have not successfully been solved. As at present an index of this kind seems to lie outside practical politics, it does not seem necessary to deal at any length

with the methods suitable to be employed in the construction of such an index. It will suffice for the moment to indicate some of the most obvious difficulties-—apart from those encountered in comparing real wages—which would have to be faced in the construction of such an index. Determining family income: There are considerable difficulties in ascertaining on a uniform basis the wages paid for work during a certain period of time. Account must be taken of payments in kind, insurance contributions, etc. When comparing the total income of a worker it is necessary to account for payments for overtime and for all other extra sources of income. It would also be necessary to take into account unemployment and short time. Moreover, the earn¬ ings of the wife and other members of the family are of great im¬ portance. At present continuous statistical information upon family incomes is not available, and it would be necessary either to commence a new series of statistics in the countries concerned, or to make very far-reaching abstractions on the basis of information of this kind con¬ tained in the national family budget enquiries and similar sources. Moreover, when calculating real wages it proved necessary to include the indirect advantages which a person enjoys as a consequence of his normal employment; it is often difficult to ascertain the value of these benefits. To obtain a correct picture of the standard of living, it is necessary to reckon with a greatly increased number of indirect benefits; free services rendered to the members of the family by States and municipalities in the form of social and educational services, hygienic measures and other activities to increase health and wellbeing, by charity, and by members of the household in the form of cooking, washing, mending, etc. It presents great difficulties to arrive at a valuation in money of these benefits as they, as a rule, have no market value. Size of family: The prosperity of a family depends ceteris paribus on how many people there are to share in the family income. This factor does not enter into the determining of real wages, but may

be a deciding influence on standards of living. Several ways could be imagined of overcoming the effects of the fluctuations in the size of the family; the most near at hand is perhaps to use a common unit of consumption, that of an "adult male" being the most generally employed.(12) It would be going too far to enter here on a detailed examination of this concept; but a few general observations will be made. An "adult male" does not in all cases mean the same thing; consequently it shares with the family a certain ambiguity as basic unit of measuring consumption. Due to differences in race, age, physical, climatological, occupational and similar circumstances, the "adult male" shows a great variety as to his needs in different times and at different places; persons with small physical needs may be as well off in coun¬ tries with low standards of consumption as persons with larger needs in countries with highest standards. The concept of an "adult male" has a definite meaning only when wre are dealing with homogeneous groups living under fairly similar conditions of life. This conditions, as a rule, is fulfilled only in national enquiries and the usefulness of the concept rapidly decreases as the comparison is extended to cover groups with dissimilar conditions of living. The variations in the needs of the "adult male" causes a further difficulty in applying the method. It has been customary to represent the needs of the other members of the family by some more or less appropriate fraction of the food of the adult male. From the point of view of international comparison, serious objections may be raised against this procedure. It has been pointed out as early as 1917 by H. C. Sherman, in the introduction to a study by L. H. Gilette(16> that "the food requirement of a man varies so greatly, according to his occupation, that it seems hardly logical to make this the basis for estimating the dietary needs See Methods of Conducting Family Budget Enquiries, International Labour Office Studies and Reports. Series N, No. 9, pp. 45-54. ) A Survey of Evidence Regarding Food Allowances for Healthy Children, New York, 1917, p. 3.

of the family. Thus a carpenter may require 3,500 calories per day, a tailor, 2,500, a 14-year-old son of either of these men, 2,800 calories. With the carpenter as a unit, the boy's requirements would be reprsent- ed by 0.8 of that of the father; but with the tailor as the unit, the allowance of 0.8 would obviously provide for too little food for the boy's needs." As occupational and similar circumstances vary widely between different countries, it is evident that the same scale universally applied would be void of definite meaning. In constructing different scales of reduction for different countries, new difficulties are created; it is always a matter of doubt whether the various scales give strictly com¬ parable results. Furthermore, the scales in actual use are practically all based on the consumption of food only. It is evident that the relations existing between various members of the family as regards the need of food, do not necessarily hold true also as to clothing, housing, cultural expenditure, tobacco, and beverages. The share of the family income that goes to various needs and members of the family is influenced not only by objectively ascertainable needs—such as is supposed to be the basis of the nutritive scales—but also by the social status of a family and by its standard of living generally. The purpose of reducing the family to a common unit of consumption, however, is to measure differences of standards of living. It turns out, however, that the scale proposed—at least partially—is a function of the phenomenon it is intended to record; it is consequently, at the best, an instrument of limited usefulness. If tastes, ideals and habits are similar, the error introduced may possibly be neglected; this is not the case in comparing countries with widely different habits of consumption and standards of living. The method should—if at all—be employed on international comparisons with the greatest reserve. IV. COMPARISONS OF FAMILY BUDGETS The Third International Conference of Labour Statisticians adopted the following resolution:

"In order to provide adequate information with regard to to the actual standards of living, enquiries should be conducted at intervals generally of not more than ten years into the income, expenditure and and conditions of living of families representative of large homo¬ genous sections of the population". The Fourth International Conference again emphasised the need of family budget enquiries in countries where such have not been made during the last ten years. In agreement with the above resolutions, the International Labour Office proposes to compile and compare the results of enquiries carried out during the last ten-year period. A study of this kind should bring together systematically the elements which constitute the standard of living and give, because of its wealth of concise information, a more vivid picture of the actual living conditions than index numbers of real wages or standard of living, into which, by the very nature of things, averages of heterogenous elements must be crammed. Perio¬ dical studies of this nature would form a useful complement to the Office studies of real wages. But it would also seem particularly useful to undertake comparisons for shorter periods of time and a group of countries for which a study of living conditions is desired (e.g. the Far East). It is not necessary here to discuss the manner in which family budget enquiries should be conducted to give comparable results. This question has been dealt with by the Office in the previously mentioned study on the methods of conducting family budget enquiries and by the resolutions passed by the Third International Conference of Labour Statisticians in 1926 (See Appendix). Very little that is new has in fact been forthcoming since that time. Experience gained later, especially in connection with certain special enquiries has only showed the need of still closer international co-operation in the preparing and conducting of national investigations. Still, however, different national enquiries show great differences in scope and methods. To make use of the extensive and valuable

material contained in the various enquiries for international compari¬ sons, it is necessary to account for at least the more important of these differences. In the absence of an analysis of the source material the risk of false or misleading conclusions is great. Some of the most important factors influencing the comparability of various enqui¬ ries are enumerated in the following; they may roughly be combined in four groups. The first group deals with the uncertainty brought into the com¬ parison by changes in the times between the carrying out of the en¬ quiries. If the conditions are stable in the countries compared, this factor is negligible, but in the case of rapid change, it is of great importance. In comparing the results of two enquiries, one of which was conducted before or during the Great War, and the other in another country during a recent year, only a little information is given as to the relation between the manner of living in the two countries at a given moment. The second group includes factors pertinent to the representative¬ ness of the investigated families. Uniformity in this respect depends upon the methods used in selecting the families whose conditions are to be compared. In the first place it is important that the enquiries should refer to the same kind of localities, or that different kinds of localities in all cases should be given a weight which corresponds to the conditions in each country. It is impossible to compare the results of enquiries which in one country include only agricultural, and n another only industrial districts. But even where the enquiries refer to industrial districts, it should be kept in mind that conditions of living vary considerably as between localities of different size even within a country. The result of a comparison will often turn out differently depending upon the weight given to large and small towns in various enquiries. It is necessary also to keep in mind differences with respect to the social and economic situation of the families compared; to be comparable, enquiries should refer to corresponding classes; in practice

budget enquiries are limited to one or two classes:—industrial wages- earners and salaried employees. But the working class especially contains many strata receiving different wages and living at different standards, and the result of a comparison is influenced by the selection of families within the working class. Generally the method of con¬ ducting enquiries through household books kept by the householders themselves tends to result in an over-representation of the better part of the working class. It is among this group that the necessary ability and interest to keep detailed records during a long period of time is most commonly to be found. But depending on many cir¬ cumstances—the interest and capability of the working class, the resources and methods of the investigating agent, etc. the degree of misrepresentation varies considerably between the different enquiries. In practically all budget enquiries it has been deemed necessary to lay down certain conditions as to the composition of the families to be included in the enquiry. Generally the families selected cor¬ respond to some notion of a "normal" or "typical" family, and consist of husband, wife, and a certain number of children. The result is that the families included in the enquiries are only exceptionally representative of the actual demographical conditions in their respective countries. As the size of the family is one of the determining factors of the standard of living it is evident that this factor must be given consideration in comparing the results. Thirdly in making comparisons it is necessary to consider the value of the material in the various studies. A small number of families or a short duration of the enquiry leaves much room for accidental and exceptional circumstances to influence the results. In drawing conclusions from studies resting on a narrow statistical basis, the greatest care must be exercised not to stress the results too far. Similarly tbe methods used in collecting the material influence the results; for instance, when the householders themselves keep their records, the results will tend to become biassed, as the better part of the working class probably is too heavily represented. It is also probable that the very fact of keeping records will influence the

habits of spending, as the householders often for the first time get a collective picture of their expenditure. An enquiry, the material for which is gained by the "enquete" or census method will have a dif¬ ferent bias, and so forth. Fourthly, the results of comparisons are influenced by the methods of compiling the material. It is from the international point of view of secondary interest to ascertain which are the best methods of com¬ pilation, as the comparability is affected by the degree of uniformity only. It is, for instance, of no consequence whether expenditure on laundry is given under the head of clothing or under "sundries", as long as it is given under the same head in all enquiries; the com¬ parability ceases first when articles in two enquiries are recorded under various heads. Where differences of this nature occur it is possible to make necessary corrections when the results are published in sufficient detail. Comparison of the percentage of income spent on the main groups of expenditure should be avoided unless the com¬ position of these groups is ascertained. Likewise in this connection the question of the statistical unit has to be reconsidered. It has already been mentioned that the family as a basic unit suffers from serious shortcomings, and that attempts to avoid them by reducing the family to a common unit of consumption has hardly proved successful. It is difficult to see any special reason why the consumption unit should be introduced here more than in previous cases and it seems at present most practical to retain the family as the basic unit of comparison. It would be easy to continue to enumerate a great many difficulties encountered when comparing the results of various family budget enquiries. What already has been said, however, suffices to show the nature of the problem and little would be gained here by giving further details. The important question is in which direction and with what force the various factors make their influence felt. In comparing any particular set of results—for instance the per¬ centage expenditure on food, clothing, and other large items of ex-

penditure, or the pecentage of the family income contributed by the various members—the first step would be to ascertain in which direc¬ tion the various factors tend to influence the results. It will be found as a rule that this qualitative analysis offers comparatively little dif¬ ficulty. It is generally easy to see in which direction each factor separately affects the result. This, however, is a thing quite different from knowing how the result of the various factors turns out in the aggregate. To ascertain this it would be necessary to measure the various influences quantitatively. As this under our present methods is out of reach, we cannot compare the various results with any degree of certitude. A qualitative analysis, however, subjective and arbitrary though it may be, is to be preferred to the uncertainty of no such valuation at all.

essay:div.essay:p: THE TANDARD OF L I V I N G I N 0 H I N A AND JAPAN. AN ESSAY ON POLICY. By C. DELISLE BURNS, D. Litt Prepared for the Fourth Bi-annual Conference of the Institute of Pacific Relations, to be held at Hangchow 1931. Issued by THE ROYAL INSTITUTE OF INTERNATIONAL AFFAIRS Chatham House, St. James's Square, London, S.W. 1.

[IE STANDARD OF LIVING- IN CHINA AND JAPAN An Essay on Policy Bv C. Delisle Burns. The standard of living of the majority of workers in the Western Pacific area is recognised to be lower than that in European countries, as the standard In European countries is lower than that in North America. To raise that standard is a primary interest of the whole world; and to say that it is a British interest does not Imply that British Interest in this matter is opposed to any other. Indeed this Is one of the cases in which a British Interest means a common Interest of all, in which the British people by their own action can share. It is assumed for the purpose here in view that the British and international interest in raising the standard of living in the East is not merely commercial or financial. Politically a rising standard of living would ensure stability and security for the future, and it would increase friendliness In International relations * Again, a rising standard of living involves cultural advance, in the extension of the applications of science to practical problems, the Improvement of popular education, the" better status of women and the increase In the use of leisure. All these ends are in view when policy aims at raising the standard; but here attention will be directed mainly to the economic aspects of the problem. The abnormal conditions of the moment - the fall in silver, internal warfare in China, and the world depression - are disregarded in what follows. The problem discussed is the more permanent deficiency of purchasing- power among the majority in China and Japan. British Economic Interests. The British interest in the standard of living in countries in the West Pacific area arises out of the importance to us of (a) exports of our manufactures to these countries, (b) openings for investment of capital there and (c) exports from these countries, some of which may be used In Great Britain. The incidental interest arising out of exports and imports is that of (d) shipping services which may be under the British flag. 1. The Royal Institute of International Affairs, as such, is precluded by Its rules from expressing an opinion on any aspect of International affairs. Any opinions expressed in this paper are, therefore, purely Individual.

All those British interests would be promoted by a higher standard of living in the East involving more purchasing power, that is to say, larger "markets" there. The increase of such markets would' increase employment in Great Britain. Policy should, therefore, be such as to secure a steady and, if possible, rapid raising of the standard. This raising of the standard of living for the majority in China and Japan is mainly dependent upon local conditions; but the action of foreign Governments and business enterprises can do much to increase the purchasing-power and improve its use among the Eastern peoples. Above all in the modern world the raising of the standard of living is an international problem, whose solution would overcome difficulties arising out of tariffs and economic nationalism. We have today in the International Labour Office and the Economic and Financial Section of the League of Nations suitable international instruments of this policy of raising the standard without fear of imperialism or of national rivalries. Examples of the British interest in a raising of the standard of living are as follows:- (a) Exports of British Manufactures to China. These have been in the' past chiefly cottorfgoods | but it would be foolish to imagine that British interests are confined to cotton exports or will necessarily always be chiefly concerned with these. The markets and the productive powers in different countries are changing; and one trade or one commodity may be displaced by another, within the whole of the export trade of any one country. Thus the cotton exports of Great Britain to China have certainly decreased, because the Chinese have purchasing- power only enough for the cheaper Japanese manufactures, but perhaps^also because of monetary conditions in China. On the other hand the value of all the exports of Great Britain to China, taken together, have not noticeably decreased. Goods from Great Britain imnorted into" China were valued at 133 million taels in 1927, 174 million in 1928 and 193 million in 1929. The goods exported were different; but it can hardly be said that British interests suffer if cotton goods, for example, are displaced In the markets by textile machinery from Great Britain. The chief British exports to China now are (*) cotton goods, of which the Department of Overseas Trade Report says "that "the more impoverished districts have noy turned entirely to the cheaper local and Japanese productions". The impoverished districts obviously are those with a deterio¬ rating'" standard of living. The recent report of the British 1. Department of Overseas Trade. Economic Conditions in China,'1930; p.55.

Economic Mission to th< .st-Lsu, is that costs of British. hav to be decreased to mee 1 this Chinese manuf ac ture will impoverishment; but clearly It would equally well suit u it would be considerably better for the Chinese, If they ■ able to buy more expensive goods. That is to say, a ra.,.. and raising of the standard of living in China result of a rise in pur cha s ing-p ower, woul d be of direct assistance to British exporters of cotton goods. See below for recent changes In the type of consumption. Wire rope is chiefly supplied by Great Britain, for the mining Industry. Rails, bars, angles^ plates,etc. would be bought if railway development occurs, which again partly depends upon a higher standard of agriculture. (iv) Engineering products and machinery. Textile machinery is incri'islngly imported from Great Britain; and this is used"to manufacture"in China cotton goods which are cheaper than those made in Great Britain. A new contract icr a ^00° spindle cotton mill in Shanghai in 1928 was secured by a British firm. in other machinery we sell flour-milling machinery and agricultural machinery, but we are losing ground in the sales ol electrical ma ch. ine r y. The trade in soda ash is practi cally all British,"......and it is increasing. vli) Fertilisers Sulphate of ammonia imports are largely from Great'BrTtaTn: The increase in the sale of fer¬ tilisers obviously depends upon raising the standard of ^inS among the vast agricultural population - not only by largei inches but by tL improvement of methods of farming .An im¬ provement In practical education of farmers in China and Japan would result in larger markets for fertilisers. 1. Report of the Cotton Mission, 1951. Is.

(k) Increase in Investments The resources of China are usually regarded as undeveloped; the investment of European and in particular British capital is "by no means large considering the size and population of the country. The economically "backward'* areas of the world at this moment lack capital0 and in most cases foreign capital supplied improves the supply of local capital. A higher standard of living in a population normally involves more accumulation of capital and a more efficient use of capital - especially in the form of "family11 capital, e.g. houses, farm-supplies, etc. But this causes an extension of banking and of the services connected with banking. In view of the important positions already held by British banks in the East, these results of a rising standard are obviously a British interest. The mere account of the capital supplied and the mere increase in banking business, however, are not half so important as the direction of the investment and the policy of the banks. That is to say," investment should favour increased transport facilities first. Finance should be the servant, not the master, of industry and commerce . The facilities or new methods in the use of credit are more important than the mere amount of credit supplied; and in a new situation old traditions and habits may be misleading. (c) Exports from China and Japan. . A higher standard of living is accompanied by greater productive power: and this productive power often shows itself in increased exports, which enter the markets hitherto supplied by older manufacturing countries . It may be falsely supposed that it is not a British interest to increase the power of China and Japan to manufacture for export, especially as in India, for example, Japanese cotton goods are obviously being sold in markets hitherto supplied by British exporters. But a British interest can never safely be confined to an interest In one trade: and in any case it could hardly be maintained that it is a British interest to obstruct the development of the export trade of countries In the Western Pacific. Indeed the increase of purchasing power In Japan,owing to the higher standard of 3.iving under industrialisation, has actually led to an Increase of Imports into Japan. Prom Japan we take silk and silk.tissue and also knitted goods, chiefly of cotton. But apart from our direct gain in the import of Japanese goods to Great Britain (It is assumed that to buy cheaply abroad is not a disadvantage to uhe buyer5.), it is clear that the industrialisation of Japan has led to Increased foreign trade between Japan and other countries. In which increase Great Britain has shared. Similarly the power of China to manufacture for her own internal markets, although it may interfere with the old markets supplied by British manufacturers, increases the purchasing power of China and opens markets for new'products which maybe supplied by British firms, if they have "the ability to grasp the

new situation. (d) Shipping Services; The carrying trade on the seas of the Western Pacific is still largely British, Hongkong depends upon a maintenance of these services. The total value of the foreign trade of China in 1929 was 2.281 million taels of which 388 million was with Hongkong! the trade with the rest of the British Empire amounted to 349 million taels. In general the markets of the world are changing, as will be noted below; and therefore British interests cannot be the same as they were in the nineteenth century. Not only has "economic nationalism'' supported the supply by each nation of its own needs, but the kinds of goods demanded are changing. A far greater proportion of non-essential goods is needed in the modern world; the production of the old staple goods is perhaps in excess of the needs of the world; but in any case British policy must look forward and not back. We must aim at securing new markets, not at retaining the old markets. New sections of^the population in most countries are providing markets for "foreign" goods; and the character of these new markets (in new goods and services) will depend largely upon changes in the standard of living. What is the Standard of Living. The standard of living is understood to mean the goods and services available for use by any person or group of persons, regarded as a whole, comparable with some other £um of goods and services. Thus the calculation of the standard involves a knowledge of (a) necessaries, - food, clothing and house-room or shelter, (b) luxuries or non-essentials including educational facilities, recreational opportunities etc. In both cases - for necessaries and "luxuries" - some of the supply is provided by expenditure of a personal money-Income (wage or salary) and some by "publicfi or co-operative agency supplying goods and services in kind. The standard therefore in any group depends partly upon a family or Individual income and partly upon public services so that the standard of living in England, for example,^is calcu¬ lated both by reference to incomes and to supplies in kind such as public education, drainage, roads, open spaces, etc. The amount of money represented for each individual or family by the public services of a civilised country It Is probably impossible to state; for the joint supply cannot be divided Into a mere collection^of units supplied. "The standard,even In economic terms, is social. The amount of vitality or energy that any person derives from

services available depends upon the whole social situation in which he finds himself. The standard of living in any country differs in different social classes of which the chief are (a) those with large incomes, (b) the "'professiomUf' workers, (c) the wage- earners and (d) the poor. The expenditure of these different classes differs greatly in most countries, and the advantages differ, which they derive from public services . But for the purpose of the argument here the standard of living of the two classes, (b) professional and (c) wage-earning, are selected for consideration.. In reference to the standard or standards of these two classes only there is a traditional contrast between the standards of different peoples or races: and that largely because the incomes of these two classes only are traditionally thought of in terms of "cost of production". Wages and salaries (one element only in the standard of living) are considered as cost of production and not as purchasing power; but obviously it is as purchasing power that they affect most deeply the international situation today. That is to s,ay, the world now needs "markets" to take up its , surplus productivity? it needs more purchasing-power, not more production - or more proeaacTtioia only ln_~scY~^^~as more production giiTelTTnc^ 'Therefore the.....consideration of the standard of' living should have primarily in view the possibility of increasing the power to purchase goods of those who at present lack power. The importance of the standard of living in China and other Eastern countries, from our point of view, is that they are potential markets, - that their peoples have less purchasing- power than they could use for efficient living. Current misunderstandings are dangerous. The comparison between standards of living is not the same as a comparison between costs of living {even in some common unit of calculation). Thus tho cost ,of living in Japan in 1913 was about half the cost of living IrTlJ.S.A. (in comparable currencies): but the standard of living in Japan may not have been lower, if the Japanese worker derived as much vitality, energy, enjoyment or social life from his expen¬ diture. Similarly today, the"cost of living for a French worker max be lower than the cost for the'"British worker; but because the French worker's food is better cooked, he derives more (in the standard of living) from a smaller wage or less earnings. Again, the social situation in different countries makes it very dangerous to compare standards of living except in very limited reference to the amount of health, etc. available in any two cases. For example, the family system in the East results in certain "costs" (maintenance of old or incompetent or unemployed members); but it also results in large "gains" (e.g. security, cheaper goods through co-operation,etc.). It is most unwise to suppose, as certain writers on China do, that the Chinese practice of maintaining theatrical performances is "waste'' or thrit it should be sacrificed in order to get more food or clothing or housing.

Raising the standard of living does not mean destroying the traditional culture of any country. The modernisation of the Chinese, for example, does not mean their "Americanisation"; for the standard of living In any country m.ay be higher than the American v/ith a far lower rate of the exchange or amount of the exchange of goods and services. With due precautions, however, it may be suggested that the standard of living (not necessarily the rates of wages) should be increased in China and Japan; that is to say., measures may be taken to eliminate disease, to diminish waste effort in transport, cultivation, etc., to reduce the death- re te, to reduce the birth-rate, to extend public services or co¬ operative enterprises in education, child, welfare, etc. Each man, woman and child and each group of human beings has a certain amount of vitality, energy and ability or intelligence . At the present time the available amount of such vitality and Intelligence is dependent upon the health, knowledge and endurance possible under the given social conditions in any corner of the world. But certain groups or certain nations have undeveloped or unused or obstructed vitality and energy: there Is more in them than comes "into play". They have capacities which have no outlets; or the capacities of the earlier years of life are stunted by lack of food or education or social stability. Such groups have a standard of living which is lower than it might be; and to raise the standard of living of such groups means not merely to give them, more productive power but also more skill in the use of such abilities as they may have and such resources as are undor their hands. The vast majority of men and women can obtain more power to use goods and services only by giving more services . What they spend Is dependent upon what they earn. But powe to earn depends upon health, bodily com¬ petence, skill and intelligence ~ ail of which again depend not only upon "the accident of birth" In each individual but also upon the store of common tradition and common dally experience available for each. The New Industrial Revolution. Tho standard is changing all over the world, not mainly in the level., but in the kind of goods and services required. Wo are now passing through a revolution in economic and cultural life, more fundamental than the so-called industrial revolution of a century ago: and therefore (1) the business and industrial policy of those in control will have to be drastically altered, if good results are to be expected and (2) the political issues in the relationships between peoples will have to be reconsidered upon a new basis.

The general character of the social revolution of today is due first to the immense increase in productive power and, secondly, to the tendency towards greater expenditure upon entirely new leisure-utilities. The Increase of productive power is occurring in almost all countries of the world, in agriculture (through mechanisation and. the application of science to crops) as well as in industry (repetition-process, rationalisa¬ tion, etc.)» This involves a much greater potential wealth por head of population in the whole world than has ever been possible in all human history. It means that distribution, not production, is our problem; for the greater wealth may not be more equally shared unless the standard of living of low-standard countries is raised. And secondly, the new revolution has given us the gramophone, the cinema, the radio, and - partly for leisure uses - the motor-car, the aeroplane, etc. This means that there arc more ways of spending income upon non-necessaries than ever- before; and the new ways are affecting not only America and Europe but also Africa and Asia. The result of a greater productivity per head of population is that the family-Income in economically advanced countries Is increasingly spent not on maintenance of children, etc but on leisure; and If the survival-rate in the world becomes stable, thus reversing the tendency to rapid Increase of population in the nineteenth century, all countries will spend more upon "luxuries" - or upon the new commodities. But this again is a problem of distribution. It is a problem of markets. Not only are the old markets in certain goods (e.g. cotton goods) proportion' ally declining, but new markets in new goods are developing (e.g. rayon, gramophones, cinemas, aeroplanes, etc.). ^Tiat the world now needs Is a policy of the market. The raising of the standard of living in China and Japan, like the raising of the standard in Africa, is essential for the absorption of the supplies available under the new system of production. The_ Present Standard in the Western Pacific. Evidence will bo before the Conference as to the actual standard of living in China and Japan. It is not possible for anyone unacquainted with those countries to make contributions to a knowledge of the facts; and "no man can see farther Into a generalisation than his knowledge of detail extends". Therefore what now follows must be regarded as merely an Impression gained by reading a small section of the available literature and a very general statement of a point of view with regard to the lives of the vast majority. This major%, without adequate voice In the direction oi policy and hitherto neglected in international affairs, Is the living body with which policy should be primarily concerned. Not

the interests of traders or financiers, nor the success of those in control of government, but the vitality and intelligence of common folk, are assumed here to be of the first importance; and it is because the farm-worker, the factory-worker^ the transport-worker and the clerk nave not an adequate share of the benefits which accrue from modern civilisation that it is pro¬ posed as a principle of policy to raise the standard of living. The immense waste in each generation of potential capacities of common folk, owing to poverty, ignorance and private•greed, makes it desirable that public policy should provide for a better dis¬ tribution of available goods and services. The West cannot claim any great superiority over the East in the principles of policy hitherto predominant. Evidence of poverty is common in all the great city-areas of the West. In Great Britain in 1924 there were more than four million persons living below the poverty-line, that is to say with less goods and services than are necessary for a barely human existence, The number in the same situation in the United States is about ten million. But knowledge and organising ability are being applied in the West to the solution of this ancient problem. It is not therefore as morally superior beings, but only because the West has acquired some skill In'the solution of problems similar to those of China and Japan, that one can consider the methods of raising the standard of living In those countries. Again, it is not suggested that the West Is wiser than the East or more generous in its policy towards other races. It is only tnat In the West we have, by trial and error, discovered some methods which may be useful for Eastern peoples to apply at their own will and for their own purposes. The missionary was typical of the West In the East In the first period of contact; the trader in the second. In the third period now beginning, the expert, the engineer and tne worker in preventive medicine are those who are typical of the West In the East. A new relation¬ ship Is arising. Raising the Standard of Living. Before considering the means by which the standard of living in the East can be raised, it may be well to note that the "recent rivalry between low wage-rates, for example, In Japan, and higher rates in Great Britain, is a sign of the rising: rate of earnings among Japanese workers. The change from domestic to industrial production generally raises the rate of earnings for the workers concerned; although it lowers the cost of production. What happened a century ago is too often'Torgotten, British manufacturers caused "unemployment" among the"hand-workers of the East by "dumping" the products of machine-labour upon the Eastern markets. The cost of production was lower in Great Britain as long as Great Britain bad the monopoly of machine labour. Now the situation is reversed. Industrialisation in the East is undercutting British goods, just as a century ago industrialisation in Europe undercut Eastern'goods . The East has been able to recover equality In manufacturing power not by lowering but by raising the rate of earnings of the workers and, through mechanisation and increased wage-rates, lowering the cost of production of Eastern goods and services • Contemporary controversies in Great Britain need not be discussed here: but it must not be assumed that a lower cost of production Implies lower wage-rates. Obviously lower costs can be accompanied by higher earnings only If there is enough brains or ability in Industrial organisation and business policy; and it Is sometimes necessary to make sacrifices or to make other people make sacrifices, if the supply of ability is Inadequate. Thus during the War a lack of brains meant the sacrifice of men in the so-called "war of attrition". On the other hand, reduction of costs Is the traditional nineteenth century method for raising the standard of living. The lower the price, the larger the market. The nineteenth century first lowered the price and then enlarged the market; but jt is not an eternal or universally applicable policy. The markets can be enlarged by (1) better salesmanship, (2) easier or more flexible credit supplies for the purchases, (3) creation oi new products or new types of product, etc. The alternative to lowering ^reduction costs in order to enter the Chinese market, for example, is a direct increase of the productivity and therefore of the earning power of the Chinese. The buyer can be given more power to buy - even by giving him more health to work with - by other means than by the seller's reduction of prices. The nineteenth century was dominated by producers5 economics.

In the relations between oeoples the economic conceptions still dominant are those of the middle nineteenth century. Competition for trie scraps of existing markets is still supposed to be the oest economic policy -"in spite of the fact that to-day the chief factor in economic life is the appearance of new markets. Ten vears ago there was no market in radio-sets: twenty years apo no market in cinemas, thirty years ago no market In gramophones. Where did the new markets come from? Irom t]^ same source as can still be tapped by imagination. But practical men still practise the mistakes of their grandfathers. ihe standard of living Is rising not by a mere extension of the market for cotton goods, but by the creation of markets In artifical silk. The whole basis of policy In foreign trade must" change, for the newer the tastes supplied, the more likely

they are to be tastes for foreign goods. Again, the ancient and threadbare controversy of Protection and Free Trade obscures the present situation. Even if every foreign product were kept out by a Protective Tariff the markets of any nation would not'be" enough to take up 'the excess of the new productive power in that nation. We are suffering - not from Malthus's pressure of population on the means of subsistence but from an opposite evil - the pressure of over-supply upon a diminishing or stable popu¬ lation. The problem is no longer one of rivalry between different nations but of distribution of purchasing-power within all nations. And similarly with regard to'the traditional Free Trade - if all the tariffs of the world were abolished some increase in the markets would, no doubt, follow as the Economic Conference at Geneva in 1927 declared; but the abolition of tariffs alone would not increase the markets sufficiently for modern productive power. The most urgent need is redistribution of purchasing-power so that the low standard countries can buy more of the supplies available. A policy of that kind requires large-scale thinking and long-range administrative and busimess ability. It requires - not rhetoric, nor "good will", nor sentimental affection between the incompetent in all nations - but hard-headed analysis of facts and clear imagination in seeing what does not yet exist. No doubt the current business of finance and. commerce requires some ability to think in statistics" but constructive policy requires more - it requires the ability to think in terms of men, women and children - that is to say in terms of the standard of living. A policy which raised the standard of living in Asia would cause the recovery of the whole world from the present economic depression,, Finally, the raising of the standard of living Is the best method for counteracting social chaos arising out of discontent or despair. Much of what is called "Communism" In Europe - whatever may be the case In the East - Is due to real distress - real lack of food and employment. Despair tends to recklessness. Those who have nothing to lose are naturally inclined to blind change; for they hope that something better may turn up and. they feel that, whatever turns up, it cannot be worse than their present situation. Therefore a real improvement in health, vitality and social intercourse - which is a raising of the Standard of living -

will secure any community against reckless adventure. The theories of Communism are beside the point. In Germany and in France certainly the movement called Communist is fomented. by actual lack of food: and It seems to one looking from a distance that In China also what is called Communism is largely the reaction*of despair against a low standard of living. To raise that standard would therefore Increase social stability. Similarly a rising standard of living for common folk prevents the growth of hostility to foreign persons or foreign goods. When men are starving, it is easy to persuade them that their sufferings are due to foreign devils" or to "Imperialistic capitalists". But If a larger supply of goods and services are available, the development of civilised life by international Intercourse will become more attractive; and there may be less tendency to international friction. This does not mean that foreign nations will be better able to have their "own way. A higher standard of living in China, for example, will increase and. not diminish the Chinese demand for the abolition of foreign privileges; but that Is all to the good. It may be said that this argument is merely the old. advocacy for buying off opposition to established oppression by offering some scraps to the barking dogs. Indeed some revolutionaries look forward to greater suffering as a means of stirring common folk to revolt. But apart from theories - common folk should have more health; and we can discuss the results upon the forms of government afterwards. It is impossible to base policy upon "the collapse of the capitalist system" or "tho danger of world revolution" or the prospects of war in the East or the decline of British exports. But as an interim policy for the situation, as it now is, a raising of fJhe "standard of living In China and Japan is desirable and attainable by quite definite measures. Such measures, even if they lead to the withdrawal of Western domination or Western privileges, will also make Eastern peoples more able to undertake the tasks of administration, judicial procedure and. constructive economic policy, upon which improvement of civilised life both In the East and in the West depends. Each Government concerned and the business organisations of different We stern nations can adopt a deliberate policy for the raising of the standard of living In the East. Pacification and the establishment of settled government is a presupposition of economic orogress. But beyond that - Governments and traders and financiers can view the field not as a battlefield of competition but as an opportunity for interlocking action, in which each promotes the Increase of purchasing-power, some of the uses of which will accrue to others. It is a better policy - even In economic terms - to cooperate for the extension of new markets

than to scramble for the remnants of a shrinking market. If the market shrinks, through famine or disorder, the best policy is not to cut costs of production but to nrevent the shrinkage of the market and to increase its power to absorb products. Expenditure on health, education and friendliness f or f oreigners ac tual 1 y does "paySi , No raising of the standard of living in the East is likely in the near future to remove ojf_ti1£lely the difficulties arising out of the relation between' 'communities which have different (not necessarily 1owe r an d highe r) s tand a rd s. These difficulties show themselves in obstacles set un to immigration and in competition in the export trades. Japanese, for example, are willing to work for less pay and under simpler conditions than those acceptable to Westerners. If Eastern people are prevented from migration, they will be Industrialised and thus forced into entering the export markets of the Western peoples. It would be fantastic to imagine that a people Is less ''civilised" if It can maintain a culture with less expenditure in the exchange of services than another people; for neither happiness nor civil¬ ised life is proportionate to the amount of income available for a man or a group of men. But the use of such Income as is available may be more or less skilful; and differences of culture or of the traditional civilisations should not obscure the fact that each culture or civilisation Is growing. To Improve the standard of living among the people of China and Japan is not to make them more like Americans or Europeans, but more able to use their own traditions and their own present abilities. The standard of living, in past times, has risen largely because of international intercourse. Great Britain is not now Inhabited by Ancient Britons or Anglo-Saxons. Woad and mead have "gone out". Artifical silk and radio-sets have come in •- largely owing to foreign trade and to the transit of odeas across frontiers. Prance was the most civilised European nation In the eighteenth century because Prance was the meeting-place for all the different European groups or nations. Thus an Institute such as the Institute of Pacific Relations is a good Instrument for that Intercourse upon which the raising of the standard of living depends. International Intercourse, however, is not only a cause of the rising in the standard: it Is also the result of such a rising. In proportion, as the standard In any country rises, the dependence of that country upon other countries increases.

N^w tastes arise, new goods and services are desired. Localism elves place to experimentalism and a new vitality displaces the fear of foreigners and the too great affection for the village- group. The final purpose of a policy of raising the standard of living therefore is the establishment of a world-order - nations of free men in a world at peace. Juno, 1931.
