essay:div.essay:p: THE SITBJUGJTTO.TJ OF A PROVINCE THE STORY -Ti^ THE I^.1I^E COUNTRY 0? VICTORIA., AUSTRALIA. By A. S. Eenycn, LI«I.3# Australia gineer, Victorian State Rivers and Water Supply Commission. Perhaps no more interesting problem in agrioultural economics exists than that ox' the development of a farm on land virgin to the plow and the farmer's flocks* In almost all cases, of course, the agriculturalist follows in the footsteps of the pastoralist; but in the Victorian Mallee, the pastoralist had occupied but small portions; indeed, by far the greater par' was covered with dense scrub and yielded nothing of %alue to man. It harboured the dingo, that deadly menace to the flocks of the squatters en the adjoining plains and that was all. "Mallee" is a well known term in Australia and is applied generally - certainly in the South Eastern States of South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria - to a somewhat stunted grou.p of Sucalypts which grow on the fringe of the arid country. The arid country embraces those areas where the annual rainfall falls definite]y below ten inches and then the Mulga (acacia aneura) takes its place. The Mallee includes Eucalyptus dumosa (once the generic term for the whole group and still often used in that way), gracilis, uncinata, oleosa, behriana, incrassata, polyoractea, viridis and some less common species. The name is of aboriginal origin and, at the inception, was spelt Mawlee, Liar lie and Mall ay • The present spelling., with a pronunciation rhyming with Sally, was adopted ahout 1850, The Mallee has a numher of stems - possibly tetter described as "branches - springing from a massive root or trunk which is "below the surface. This halit of growth is distinctly due to the arid conditions of its life #nd permits of a considerable storage of moisture. The roots are a well known and favorite fuel. Amongst this scrub the mound-building Mallee hen, leipoa ocellata, is found. LOCATION. .Administration from a distance of 13.000 miles gave to Victoria as a western boundary a straight line, the 141st meridian. If it had thought of making a parallel, that of 36°, the boundary on the north, it would have excluded practically the whoie of what is known as the "Mallee Country". In other words, the Mallee country lies

north of the rest of Victoria and embraces the north-western part of that State. It is differentiated from the river plains forming the surrounding country by its vegetation and by the absence of any system of watercourses. It obtained its name from the dwarf forms of Eucalyptus to be found all over it and, in places, exclusively occupying its surface. It is roughly triangular in shape, having the Murray River on the north, the South Australian boundary on the west, and on the south and east a line, more or less straight, running from Swan Hill in a general south-westerly direction to Dimboola, and thence west to the South Australian boundary. Detached portions known as the Little Mallee, between the Avoca and Loddon Rivers, and the Little Desert south of Nhill, complete the Mallee area. All told, it embraces over one-fifth of the State, or more than 11,000,000 acres. Not only is it marked out by its physical features, but it is separated from other crown land in legislation. Special inducements and conditions were needed for its successful settlement, whether pastoral or agricultural* DESCRIPTION. The eleven million acres are not covered with dense low scrub, nor is the country flat, as popularly supposed. There are four general divisions - the scrub country, generally consisting of sandy ridges running easterly and westerly with red loam flats all covered with mallee from eight to twenty feet in height, probably 50 per cent of the whole; the broken country, consisting of open, grassy plains, pine and belar ridges, big mallee up to sixty*feet in height and all sorts of smaller trees, such as quandongs (fusamis). pittosporums, hakeas, grevilleas, heterodendrons, mycporums, eremophilas, acacias, &Cc, mostly peculiar to the area as far as Victoria is concerned; the heath country, of infertile white sands, generally in steep blown hills," covered with epacridae and sandy loving forms of vegetation, banksias, casuarinas, hakeas &o., and stunted forms of mallee, the frontage country to the Murray River, with its large box and led gum flats and bordering pine and hop bush countryo More or less every¬ where is found the "porcupine" grass (triodia irritans) - "Ballarock" or "Wallock" ef the blacks, erroneously given as "Spinifew" on many official plans. It is rarely found on the heathy country, and more rarely on the best class of land. There occur also in the northern portion considerable areas under saltbushes. EARLY OPINION. Yery little has been yet written about the Mallee Country, and little of that is laudatory. Even the blacks gave the early settlers alarming accounts of its trackless regions and of reptiles miles in length which awaited the luckless traveller who dared enter. Mothers threatened their children with its horrors if they misbehaved. Nehemiah Bartley, who was on the Murray

irontage in the early fifties, thus describes it : TTA level country of poor yellow soil, destitute alike of stones, water or inequalities of any kind. This soil is oovey-ed [ as thickly nearly as they will grow) with bare saplings twelve feet long and two inches thick of the Eucalyptus Duinosa, "bearing a tuft of leaves only on the top, and springing, perhaps, a dozen cf these dreary sticks from a root, or ball, that rises just above the ground; this only and nothing more of any kind; no birds, no insects, no animals, for there is nothing for them to live upon, and only a rare snake. Woe to the traveller who gets lost in this terrible desolation; he can see no distance; he can climb no hill; and if the Mallee sticks would bear him on the top, he would only see Mallee, Mallee, Mallee all around him'T.$~:Pr. Neumayer was not impressed with its possibilities. Describing the country south of Kulkyne, most of which is broken country and of gotd quality, he writes "that horrible rogion covered with porcupine grass and stunted scrubs. The sandhills are so numerous that one might with no great difficulty, imagine oneself tc be amongst tho hummocks on the soc-shoro*••••• Eere and there the monotony of the Mallee scrub was broken by groups of fino pine trees, otherwise nothing else was to be seen and not a sound to be heard."/ The climax is reached, however, in the description due to Mr*A»Patchett Martin, then Secretary to a Royal Commission on'Crown Lands, who as a result of a trip in 1878 over Dr. Neumayer1s route from Swan Hill to Eulkyne, and thence by Tioga and Yollumgip to the settled country, is responsible for the following fine piece of word painting, which it has been tho fashion to quote in most reports on the Mallee. It must be remembered, however, that at that time the lessees, who had no term of tenure of these holdings, united in presenting everything in the most repellent aspect, partly, it may bo surmised, to reduce payments, but mainly to discourage any outsiders attempting to come in, Mr. Martin wrote referring to the Mallee country generally: - "The aspect it presents is that cf a wilderness in the strictest sense of the term - sand, scrub, and mallee below, the scorching sun and bright blue sky above, and not a sound of life to break the solemn silence. In a journey of 100 miles from north to south, not one solitary # "Opals and Agates" p.62, N# Bartley, Brisbane, 1892. I "Results of the Magnetic Survey of the Colcny ^J^01:^' executed between the years 1858 and 1864", Trip 111 (with Burke and Wills to tho Darling and through the MalleeJ. George Neumayer, Ph.D.. Mannheim, 1869

bird or living creature was to be seen. Even the scream of the parrakeet was not to be heard. The only evidence of animal life was the barked stems of stunted scrubs and bushes where the rabbits had been feeding and the dead carcasses of a few dingoes which the trapper had wnared and poisoned. Some native wells, a lagoon or two, and a few small muddy waterholes are to be met v/ith scattered far apart over an area extending over some thousands of square miles, but they are more frequently found dried up than otherwise. All through this parched country there is no grass." fp RAINFALL. The rainfall for the Mallee is not only variable in its annual totals, but also in its seasonal distribution. In the south-west, near Serviceton, 75 per cent of the annual precipitation falls in the eight wheat-growing months, whereas near Suston at Bumbang, less than 62 per cent falls in the same period. Again, in the eastern and northern portions, the total rainfall for a year may be as little as four inches, while in the western, and southern parts the minimum annual falls are in some cases not less than eleven or twelve inches. The rainfall in any one year is not, however, such an important factor as might at first be thought. Where fallowing is practicable - and practised it must be if settlement is^to be successful - excellent and very profitable crops have been raised on less than four inches of rain"during the growing period. The yields obtained by the best Mallee farmers are about the same throughout, though the rainfalls of the different parts of the district vary very much. The average fall over the whole Malleo is fourteen inches, with a range from nineteen in the south to eleven in the extreme north-west. It has been proved that wheat farming can be carried on profitably where the annual rainfall is as low as ten inches. A marked peculiarity of the Mallee is the great variability of the soils. The best class is a red sandy loam with a subsoil much resembling the surface, but containing a greater percentage of clay. There is always more or less grass, r.nd numerous plains occur. Where the mallee bush predominates the soil is generally lighter in colour and. contains more clay, the subsoils in some cases being fairly tough. The vegetation is generally mallee, more or less low in habit, depending upon the number of fires which have swept it and the #= Keport of the Crown Lands Commission of Enquiry, Victoria, 1879,

period elapsed since tho last. In the ordinary malleo country there is at times a considerable amount of limestone, mostly travertine. Victorian farmers ■ generally look upon limey land v/ith distrust, but South Australian farmers, who are good judges of poor land, havo a better opinion of it. There are considerable areas of salt bush country generally associated with salt lakes and copi (gypsum). It is practically worth¬ less for agriculture. Mallee soils are in such a condition of aeration from their lacustrine and aeolian origin and of desiccation from their arid situation that none of the accepted standards as to quality is of service in judging an analysis of these soils. They are practically devoid^of humus, and become for lengthened periods, especially in the subsoil, devoid of all interstitial and capillary moisture. A fair average Victorian mallee soil, yielding in favorable seasons over 30 bushels of wheat to the acre, contains about .5 per cent potash (K#0) against .25 per cent the accepted standard for a good soil, .04 per cent -ohosphoric acid L$z0q) against .15 per cent, 1 per cent of lime (CaO) against .5 per cent, and .08 per cent nitrogen against .15 per cent. The great deficiency in phosphoric acid is readily made up by dressings of from one-half to one hundredweight of superphosphate of 18 r)or cent v/ater soluble phosphoric acid contents or- 36 per cent calculated as monocalcic phosphate, No beneficial result has been attained by othor dressings, such as nitrogenous manures. In South Australia the mallee soils contain less phosphoric acid, averaging about .02 per cent and heavier dressings of superphosphate are successfully employed. The alkali contents of Victorian mallee soils vary very much. Unfortunately, very few determinations of them are available. The chlorine contents also vary greatly. Where in large quantity, it is, in the form of common salt, generally found associated v/ith sulphate of lime or gypsum. In the surface soils in the wheat-growing areas" it is generally under .01 per cent, but reaches as high a figure as .15 per cent. (The figures given are for chlorine. Sixty-five per cent should be added to bring them to the equivalent of common salt or sodic chloride). The latter instance is one of the best Victorian mallee soils, which yield very large returns of wheat. In the subsoils the salt contents are much higher. Crops of hay, oats, and wheat have been profitably grown on soils containing much larger quantities of salt than thoso figured above, and having, in addition, very large percentages of gypsum; land so salt that its natural vegetation is practically all samphire or beadbush (salicornia Australis). Very _4.^4>^4.^, ^cmO+p Vn^n ^ 1 r-~ * r> r>~ ^4-onr-.or1 -from P.nl.Lg-------------------------------

carrying mallee scrub mixed with saltbush (atriplex sp.), but cultivation of thoso exclusively growing saltbush or bluebush (kochia sedifolia) has not boon so successful, these soil ■ being generally too heavy and too clayey for the light rainfalls. It may be broadly stated that the sandier the soil the lower its apparent value by analysis, though this is not confirmed by actual experience in culti¬ vation* Red sands are the richest. Yellow sands are t)oor, while white sands unless of no great depth and over¬ lying a clay subsoil are practically worthless. Observation of the class of soils, and particularly of the vegetation growing upon it, will yield the only reliable result. So far, soil analysis has only proved a hindrance to mallee settlement, and had it been heeded, some of the best districts in this and the adjoining States would still bo unsettled, instead of turning out yields of up to 45 bushels to the acre. V/ATER SUPPLY. The adjoining Wirnmera district and the Malleo country are remarkably well served by probably the most extensive, comprehensive, and effective individual schcmo of domestic supply channels existing in any part of the v/orld. The scheme serves 11,000 square miles ^o± territory, of which over 7,000 square miles are within the Mallee country. For this purpose there are storages at Lake Lonsdale, Fyan's, Taylor1s, and Pine Lakes, and Wartook of a total capacity of 200,000 acre feet, and •oublic channels aggregating 6,000 miles in length. The greatest distance the water travels from storage is .300 miles - to Annuello, in the Mallee. There are approximately 12,000 holdings, each with its own excavated tank or reservoir, which is filled from the channel system, no matter how great its capacity once a year during the cool months. In addition, no less than 40 towns are supplied with water through pipe reticulations. Other systems, the supply of which is by pumping from the River Murray, serve the Coreena, Carwarp and Millewa districts. Where bore water is unobtainable and channel extensions are not immediately practicable, tanks, dependent upon local catchment, are put down. They vary from 200 cubic yards, covered, to 50,000 cubic yards, dopending upfen the area and quality of catchment, twenty acres being generally reckoned as required for each 1,000 cubic yards. A recent innovation is the making of what are known locally as "ironclad" catchments. In these, sheets of flat galvanised iron joined together are laid upon half an acre of sloping ground: the run-off, closely approximating 100 per cent, is caught in a ooncrete-lined, iron-rooiea tank of 65,000 gallons capacity. This combination, in a district of twelve inches annual average rainfall with u

minimum of four inches, yields 90,000 gallons per annum, with a safety margin of over 30 per cent* This volume. which can be° used as needed, is ampl. ' for the yearly requirements of six persons, ten horses, two cows and one hundred and fifty sheep. The system has proved itself. In the south-west of the Mallee - an area bounded by the Wirnmera River and its extension to Pine Plains on the east and the 35th parallel on the north - underground water of a useful quality is obtainable. It is struck at depths of 100 to 600 feet under beds of estuarial blue clay and in marine limestones of miocene age. It rises to'levels of from 300 feet to 15D feet above ordinary low water (Kobson's Bay), and has a northerly gradient. In low localities, salt bush and copi country, its hydraulic level is higher than the surface, and it becomes artesian. In most parts the surface level is too high, and the water has to be lifted by pumping, tho lift being as great as 250 feet. Generally the motive power employed is windmills, twelve feet in diameter, with thirty feet towers. Outside the area mentioned, salt water only has been found by boring. FARMING METHODS. The first operation in bringing the land into productive occupation is to get rid of the scrub. This can only be effected over a period of time, which at the best is four years, and should not exceed six or seven years. If the vegetation is of a light order, say scrub not more than ten or fifteen feet in height, it is rolled down by the well-known mallee roller, drawn by bullock or horse teams, and occasionally by traction engines - steam or oil. Horse teams require skilful driving, and all large mallee trees must be well "nicked1 , or there is a considerable risk of injury to the teams. In the case of the larger mallee, or of pine or buloko country, cutting down by hand is resorted to. In this case, cutting stumps axe"handle high is sometimes done, the branches being piled around the stumps which are scorched and frequently killed outright. The cost of rollin. which is frequently dene by contract, varies from 3s.6d. for very light low mallee and broom scrubs to 4s.6d. and 6s. for the heavier mallee; hand cutting starts at about 7s.6d. per acre, and will go up as high as 15s. The rolling"or cutting must be done in the winter months, July to September, in order that a fair grov/th of shoots may- have occurred before burning-off time (February to April inclusive). Burning off, which involves the clearing of a chain strip around the whole of the rolled area as a fire¬ break, costs a few ponce per acre, and if lucky in the

weather and the amount of scrulD on the ground, practical .'.J no picking up will te required after the "burn. If unlucky, the cost of picking up will amount to shillings - sometimes 4s. per acre. The horse-rake or scrub-rake is sometimes employed to rake the branches and sticks into rows. If the mallee has teen somewhat large, a further cost of up to 9d per acre is needed for snagging, i.e. cutting off the jagged or pointed pieces of the broken stumps," which may lame the horse teams when working the ground, No other ^reparation - save in the heavy lands, which form only a small percentage - is needed for the first crop, so that the cost of preparation will vary ±rom about 4s/to 10s. Into this natural seed-bed - the loose sandy surface soil covered by a thin layer of ashes - abcu, 45 lbs. of wheat and 30 lbs. of superphosphate are drilled immediately after the first autumnal rains - April to June. The'disc drill, up to 21 hoes, is the preferable implement. In the heavy lands, a preliminary ploughing, or'skim-ixLoughing, with the stump-jump plough is desir-D±e, and in this case in general the superphosphate manuring may be omitted. Shoot cutting will probably not oe necessary, and, if a decent crop be obtained, resultant stubble after harvesting - with the stripper preferably in the early stages cf development - will give a fcurn SiicX will effectively destroy all the shoots. In fact one burn may be put down as equal to two cuttings mis results as to killing tho mallee roots. In the_second year, a one-way disc cultivation, or skim-ploughing, is advantageous. For light soils, the superphosphr.te dressing may new be increased, and for the heavy lands put on for the first time. In the third and fourth ye rsn increased amount of cultivation - an amount *£ioh oanbo better judged by the farmer himself than can be ^dic^ted in words -should be done. If four good burns tove been secured after the first four crops, practically^ th wholo of the stumps or roots will have been killed i± ^' another two years must elapse before the land is fit for gco. farming. Shoots will need cutting with a slasher about &f o later, in each year. The cost varies from 94. to tl'vel acre!' During the period referred to the slump- jump plough and other implements will have been °£ntinu 11, pulling up roots. These need picking up, and if possible, cartirj off and stacking for use as fuel later on, I i more general, though mole wasteful, to burn *^.j" ^f * paddock. Reverting to the oommenoement of °P°*f ^'^ is advisable for the farmer to put in every aoro that ho can possibly manage. With ordinary te.,ms say eight horses, the settler himself, with but little assistance, should'be able to cultivate from Ooo to 600 acres. With a tractor this area may bo doubled. ihis lo desir-Die,

that tho whole of the farm "be "brought into profitable cultivation at the earliest possible period, and also io avoid the risk of the remaining stp.nding groen mallee "being "burnt. Burnt mallee cannot "be cleared, unless at, an additional cost of at least 4s. to 5s. per a.cre, until five or six years after the burn. When the roots are killed, a completely different method of farming must be undertaken. About one-third ef the total area is to be ploughed from July to September fo .' fallow; one weed-harrowing in October (if the spring "be good, two) will be required. During the summer, November -j March, the surface must be stirred, preferably with discs, in the case of any heavy rain tending to form a surface crust. The crop will be put in v/ith the autumnal rains, May - June, and, in general, with the fifth stroke of the implements over the paddock, though instances of over twenty four strokes are not uncommon and v/ith corresponding profit*- After harvesting, the paddock is allowed to remain in stubble and grass for about sixteen months, v/hen it is again fallowed; thus one crop only is obtained in three years. In the meantime, the other portions of the farm are treated likewise, so that the farmer has v/ith the fallowing system one-third of his total area under crop each year. The average yield during the shoot-killing, or "scratching" period, is from six to eight bushels per acre. In the fallowing period, the average yield should be from twelve to eighteen bushels. It is essential, the first one or tv/o years perhaps excepted, to keep a flock of sheep to eat off the crop in winter, preventing it growing too rank. Under ordinary conditionst a 700-acre farm should run comfortably 150 sheep; attention should be particularly directed to the rearing of fat lambs for the market. Settlers following out"more or less, as circumstances permit, the above general system have been exceedingly sue cos sful f i nan c i ally. The value of unimproved Mallee land covered with scrub and without railway communication can hardly be stated in figures. It is, to all intents and purposes, worthless. In proximity tc a railway line - say, within ■ fifteen miles and with an'assured water supply, its value in ordinary times, becomes from £2.10s. to £8 per acre. These figures include the improvements, which may be put down at from £1 to £1.10 per acre and upwards, HISTORY OF SETTLEMENT. The Victorian Mallee has passed three distinct periods. The first, that of discovery and exploration: the second, of pastoral occupation divisible into cattle and sheep with the rabbit, 187R-B9, finally triumphant: the third the golden era of wheat. Agricultural occupation did not begin until 1885, following

upon the passing of the Mallee Pastoral leases Act 1883, Under this act, Mallee lands on the "fringe" were classed as allotments: those further in were called "blocks. leases expiring in 1903 were obtained by auction. ir. South Australia first had come the stripper, the Mullenlslng method of scrub clearing and cropping, the Mallee roller and the stump-viumTD slough, all South Australian inventions and of startling originality and of equally startling practical profit. The scrub was no longer a place to get lost in: fortunes were to be picked up without any outlay in particular of capital. The allotments were subdivided into holdings cf 500 to 1£00 acres with a transferred tenure of balance of lease only. Such well-known names as David 31der, Isaac Younghusband, Pharez Phillips, Andrew Anderson and greatest of all, Sdward Harewood lascelles, were the leaders in settling these lands. Amending Acts were passed in 1885 and 1889. The Government urged to action by the private subdividers, started m 1888 and in three years, got rid of half a million aores, considerably in excess of the private results. The first bad drought - a very bad one - in 1902, halted the march. Some four million aores had been settled, and success¬ fully. The "fringe" had gone. The "interior belt , of close u-oon 2,000,000 acres of good wheat land and the "Murray" frontage" of as many more, v/ere waiting. Not until 1908 was a start mo.de to throw open the "interior belt". Subdivision started almost simultaneously at three points - at Murrayville, adjoining Pinnaroo, on the South""Australian boundary; at Ouyen, on the previously constructed line to the Mildura Irrigation Settlement; and north of Lake Tvrrell, near the terminus of the Bendigo to Ultima railway line. Profiting by previous and some¬ what bitter experience an effort was made to prevent, as far as possible, the considerable period of non-production usually*accompanying the early years of settlement, due to the natural difficulties caused by absence of railways, roads and v/ater supply. Ahead of the settler, or at any rate, contemporaneous with his arrival, railway lines were constructed," roads wore located to avoid bad arid sandy patches, grubbed clear of all stumps to a width of 16 ft. 6 in., and metalled with limestone rubble m very bad places, while as complete systems of water supply as immediately practicable were established, father inducements to early occupation and production wore given bv suspending payments for the purchase of the !Und for a period of three years, provided the settler put on an equivalent in excess of the improvements stipulated in th. conditions of his lease; by advances of up to 60 pe- cent of the value of his improvements, ana by some mmox

concessions. Tho effectiveness of these innovations was demonstrated early. Out of 103,000 acres thrown open and allotted in 1909 at "Murrayville, no less than 55,000 acres wore under cultivation in 1910, yielding over 600,000 bushels. Bv 1919 the greater part of the "interior belt" had been subdivided, and a start made on the "Murray frontage", Tho Hillewa area, 850,000 acres, served by the Red Cliffs- Meringur railway has been allocated; there remains nearly half a million acres of agricultural land - 200,000 in Hillewa, 90,000 at Pino Plains, 60,000 on the Cutlet Crook, and 150,000 in scattered portions. Altogether eight and a half million acres have been settled. Tho cost of thoso' road and water supply works is actually defrayed by tho settlers. An addition of 3s. per acre was made to tho purchase price. Throe-fifths of this is sDont on roads and water supply in approximately equal portions. No charge is made for railways nor is any local rate charged. Complete and reliable schemes of water supply put in later are paid for by rates covering interest^depreciation, redemption, and working expenses; the average charge is £15 per annum per square mile. An annual supply of about 4,000 cubic yards of v/ater to each farm is provided. WII5AT YIELDS. For the first twenty-six years of the Mallee's life - that is up to tho great drought of 1914/15, for in those arid areas verging upon the infertile, it is by the droughts that tho poodle date their events - the average wheat yield will soem impossibly low judging by standards of elsewhere. It was six and a half bushels per acre sold at the railway stations by the farmers at 3s.ltjd# per bushel, - a gross return per acre of £1.0.3^d. Yet on this • but boar in mind it was pro-war when standards and ideas were somewhat different - there was developed from the abandoned Lialleo territory, supporting at tho outside a few score persons and perhaps 10,000 sheep but breeding an infinity of rabbits, foxes and dingoes, a province in¬ habited by over 60,000 farmers, artisans and tradesmen, an average of nearly 100 acres of alienated land per individual. There were built up nine railways, 650 miles in length, IB important and over 30 minor townships, 2500 miles of water channels, numerous public water storages and town water supplies, public buildings of all sorts adding to the State1s incom© several million pounds per_ year/ In tho year 1915, there were one and a half million acres under wheat yielding close upon 20 million bushels. Since 1915, tho average yield has nearly doubled. ^e figures for the la»t season, one of the most disappointing

experienced for a long while wore 2,722,000 aoros cropped., the yield averaging 9ij bushels per aore, a total of 25,421,000 bushels. An examination of the records combined with some aboriginal traditions confirmed by observations of the first settlers shows a remarkable cyclical succession of v/et years. About tho beginning of each off decade, 1830.. 1850, 1870, 1890, 1910 - and it is to be hoped 1930 will not prove an exception, at any rate it has started well ■ thero occurs a sequence of four or five good seasons. Then there are sequences as long of indifferent or poor years with small runs of good seasons. The result of those sequences is during the run of good seasons to send up land prices above their true level and to convince the farmer that he is the beneficent agent and not the climate. Each good year is followed by a reduction in the area cropoed per farmer and what is worse, by a reduction in the quality of the cultivation, shown by a diminished yiold proportionately to the rainfall. The lean years have their value as they bring the farmer back to his bearings. Keeping in mind that bringing the scrub into production proceeded naturally from better conditions of soil and rainfall to the worst in Victoria, so that without an improvement in agricultural methods there should have been on the average a continual diminution as the poorer country was brought into subjection, the following figures of acreages and yields will repay some attention. Unfortunately though promises or half promises were made that the price would he maintained, the great slump came just before the harvesting of "by far the greatest acreage ever sown to wheat in Victoria. The farmer had to accept what he could got, guarantee or no guarantee, and that was the lowest price known for neo,rly 40 years, a Drice that in all cases where the wheat was produced under a system of hired labour, was under the cost of production. The years 1898 and 1900 lust escape being included with a 5s and 6.,, average respectively. If they be put in, there was a sequence of eigbt bad seasons from 1895 to 1902 inclusive, cul¬ minating in the latter year in what, despite a slightly better average yield than 1914, was the record drought. It the tlm'lhere wer. indications, both botanic and physiographic, that a very long period, poss^ °^f £ies' had elapsed before its predecessor ana that thGr^°^m.^al similar time would elapse before a repetition. Summing up, wo find in tho 42 years of MOM*, ten average years, 24 per cent; .. .. 16. years four bushels above ana 16 years four bushels below tho average, 6b p.r oen

each; 17 per cent of good years and 21 per cent of poor seasons. An undue proportion of the poor seasons occur in the early period 1889/1914 when the settlement was .almost wholly in the better soil and better rainfall areas* The effect of better methods of farming due to some extent also to the greater facilities afforded to the settler is reflected in the following figures: average yield from 1889 to 1914, 6i bushels: from 1915 to 1930, 10£ bushels.. It will be seen that the extension of settlement north¬ wards into the area later termed "The Newer Mallee" did not have a harmful effect, quite the contrary* The necessity for some instruction of the new settlers, particularly the returned soldier settlers,often, nay mostly, devoid of any Mallee experience and indeed of either farming knowledge or aptitude, was forced on the Government. Experimental plots to demonstrate the best wheat varieties and the more profitable methods of cultivation were inaugurated. Supervisors, some at least with the requisite experience were appointed: but un¬ fortunately their chief activities were connected with finance, and however grateful the appearance of the officer who is to make advances on improvements, may be, the feeling of indebtedness incurred and of future re¬ payments has a repelling effect: and when he has to press for payments or has to refuse an application for an advance, the good understanding which must prevail if advice is to be given and taken, is destroyed and with it the supervisor's usefulness. To obtain good results from agricultural advisers, complete divorce from all financial matters is the first essential. The debt collector is never a welcome visitor. FINANCS - INITIAL CAPITAL. Investigations into the progress of so111 ernent made in 1915 showed that the average capital or as it may be better put, the average excess of assets over liabilities of the average settler on the interior Mallee blocks was a little under one hundred pounds. This was, in almost all cases, made up of waggon, implements, and teams, often in excess of the figure mentioned but set off by a fair amount of debts brought from his last attempt. To visualise properly the position of the Victorian Mallee settler, it Iris to be well realised that in this State, the Mallee country is the Cinderella of the rural districts, and it is not the resort of the farmer who has been successful elsewhere. It is somewhat different in the neighbouring State of South Australia which has a very large proportion of its rural areas on the margin line of surety. There the Mallee wheat areas which adjoin those of Victoria, being separated simply by an imaginary line, the 141st Meridian, are looked upon with favour and a farmer,

successful during favourable seasons in the low rainfall areas, will apply for Mallee lands. In this case, he is in a good financial position, and having learnt by hard experience, is generally found to retain .and improve thab position. Hence where Victorian Mallee areas have been thrown open adjoining South Australia their success has been over the average. FINAIICE - CAPITA! INVOLVED* However, the position is, the settler upon the virgin lands of the Mallee equipped with his hundred pounds, has now to face the problem of handling a business proposition involving at least four thousand pounds of capital. Tho Government assists by handing over to him at a nominal figure paid over a period'of forty years without interest, some thousand acres. This may be taken to have a potential unimproved value of two pounds per acre* His minimum requirements in working and grazing stock, implements, material and sustenance for the earliest period in which he can obtain a return for his labour eighteen months, cannot be set down at loss than fifteen hundred pounds. Deferred outlay, for further clearing, house, sheds, fencing and water supply is on a very conservative estimate, five hundred to a thousand pounds. To meet all this, he possesses his paltry hundred pounds. His right or interest in the un¬ improved value of his land is a non-negotiable one for the first six years during which he is simply a tenant of the Grown. True, he may acquire a valuable transferable interest by either insolvency or death; but not a personal one. Originally, that is prior to the repatriation movement subsequent to the return of our coldiers from the Great War the deficiency in capital was made up by private credit, not based upon the small capital brought in nor u-oon the hypothetical value of the block allotted the settler: but upon the settler himself. In other words, the private creditors, who embraced the storekeepers, the rolling contractors, the stock and station agents, the implement makers and the fertiliser firms, backed their judgment as to a man1s ability to make good by giving him credit. Naturally enough this implied dear money, that is dear to the settler: but in the long run highly profitable to the creditor. Yet it was accompanied by such a discriminative system of selection in the first place and in tho second place by such a rigid restriction of spending on the part of the farmer that it, m practice, proved quite successful and satisfactory. The substitution of a Government system of advances unaccompanied in uhc first Place by any drastic system of selection and after by severe restriction, has resulted in advances being

looked upon as a right, and almost, it might be said, as remuneration, a credit instead of a debt. Evidently incurring debt is inevitable in the first two or three years of'a Mallee settler1s career, but with a good or even a fair season or two, there should be no further burden, no millstone of debt around his neck. The investigation already referred to showed that the average settler had improved his position by somewhat over one hundred and fifty pounds yearly, and that at the end of his six years tutelary period he was worth eleven hundred pounds or one thousand more than he started with so that within that time he had got a good way on the job of accumulating the necessary capital to make his farm his own. This of course was not in cash but was represented by improvements to his farm by stock and by implements. The value, however, was there and in ordinary times readily realisable. Unfortunately, at the end Oi the six years, the farmer's title to his block became negotiable, advances on mortgage by banks, financial firms and trustees became possible: and rejoicing in the removal of the irksome restrictions of the past the farmer had a good time for a while. FINANCE - GENERAL. The later experience from 1919 onwards, of the substitution of a statutory and universal system of Government credit for the severe restriction oi private credit has not had the results that economical theories would lead one to expect. In place of cropping to provide some saleable product to bring in cash, much effort has been diverted to improvements, houses, sheds, fences, dams, and so on which however necessary and profitable in theory, have not helped to keep the farmer out of debt: but have actually landed him further in> the mire. These results concomitantly with a succession of seasons below the average, some being disastrous, have led manv persons with a recent and superficial knowledge only to'condemn Mallee settlement or at the best to class it as marginal or precarious. If land settlement be postponed in every case where a general economic survey made in the early stages throws doubt upon the possibilities of profitable production, there would have been no agricultural settlement in Northern Victoria. Even Victoria itself during the crisis of 1839-1841, when production was ten pounds per head and living costs over sixty, would have boon returned to King Jagga Jagga and abandoned; vet in 1848, prosperity was at a greater oitch than any period since. The same gloomy aeauctions and even blacker prophecies have been made of the Goulburn Valley, the loddon Plains and the Wimmcra country. Time has h^d its rovenge and nullified them .11.

The Mallee country, not so long ago Ism fa ^ community than Bass Straits which did at lea.,t prouuc^ some fish, has since its opening oontrxtutel 380,000,000 hushels of wheat to Victoria's granary. In the time o± Victoria's greatest stress through war and drought, it In 1916 Produced 23,464,000 hushels and last year^ove, 25,000,000 hushels, more than half the btate s tot..l yield. FINAMOB - POST OF gaOPUCTION. Some little consideration ^t now he given the so-calied cost of production. Professor Perkins in South Australia working,as most of the farmer's investigators do, on the assumption th-.t land values are constant and have to * V'^?™ Iltl oer recent hoom rates, made the cost of production 4/11 per hushel- why not the full 5 - is not apparent. Other estimates varied. The Burrumhuttock branch °**** Farmers and Settlers Association near Albury, New South Wales, made the cost 7/- on a 640 acre farm. True, the total annual cost of £1440-10-0 included only £242 actual out-of-oocket expenditure for agricultural work. In the Wim,mera District where wheat growing has heen carried r^nf fromnnVo\ 10?^ oi Isslmlng that the value of the land was knownhefore tho profit^ or otherwise, of wheat f^mg, had heen ascertained. In these estimates and the ratio applies generally, ahout two-thirds of the cost is intereot depreciation and similar hypothetical charges. One striking feature is that all these a8*1"?*^ ^ *y the farmers themselves adopt a yield much above that actually obtained in the district and irequently doublo an exemplification of the farmers knowledge of *^xr own shortcomings. It is noticeable also that £h^"^no;;0& vary with the market price, though always keeping ,-bove it. The latest Wimmera Societies' efforts put 8b.14. as the cost of production. A Mallee one from Walpeup Is 3s!ofd? Other estimates, based on actual cash °^lay °nly, made the cost per bushel at Carwarp X/5 and at «<9"xmull U., buth in the extreme north of the Mallee. In South Australia where for the moment the so'^f ^^ftion phrases, home maintenanoe area and cost of Pro^°^0^' w t flrnt>oad in favour of "the self-contained farm one f'rLr Pleading man with a residence and conveniences morTof the high"class suburban oraer than a rustic dwelling, disclosed an outlay for " "OE.hB for ox- stores End provisions for six persons of undex &*' * killed his own meat, had his own muk, butt a. , oheeso, eggs and vegetables, baked his own gristed flour,

to buy sugar, coffee, tea and such things as washing soda though this last might have "been done without had he known that his Mallee ashes would yield him potashes, or carbonate of potash, equally useful. As he produced 15,000 bushels and his other costs, sacks, fertiliser, rates, duplicates, etc., would not exceed £650, his cost approximates to that of the Werrimuil figure. Near Huston"in the Victorian Mallee, one farmer, a tractor one, crops and harvests 1000 acres without any assistance, Eis cost'is in the same group. It will be seen that almost any figure may be made up by adding all sorts of quite legitimate charges. Yet in spite of these continued losses by production below cost, land values in rural Victoria steadily rose until they reached for v/heatgrowing land, absurdly high figures. In the Wirnmera where the three and four year rotation systems are in vogue, land sold steadily at from £25 to £30 per acre. After all, in the early period (1889-1914) of the Mallee, prosperity and a good solid prosperity at that was achieved with an average yield of 6i bushels per acre netting for the farmer 3/1^ aer bushel at the railway siding, just over one ^ound ^er acre as already stated. Since then d^- 19301 the vield has been 10i bushels and the price 4/4d. or £2-5-6 tier acre. There certainly have been more motor cars, more^wireless sets and more luxury generally; but the ^resent low rjrice of wheat will call for much self- denial if the farmer is going to pull through. Whether he can pull through and cut his coat according to his cloth, will depend largely upon the lowering of ™e prices of secondary products in a similar ratio to the primary ones. The old spirit is there, the trammels o± legislation and doctrinaire administrators need casting off: that is all, 05ILBRAL. There are some miner difficulties connected with the bringing of virgin land into farming production. In the agricultural settlement of pastoral lands, a system of roads and road transport is already in existence, ana its extension or intension is all that is required. On the other hand, with virgin scrub, the construction ot a railway at the outset is imperative. As economical con¬ siderations prevent railway construction being ahead o± settlement, they have to proceed pari passu, Thisleaas to difficulties in the running of construction trams to time tables, the settler depending upon them ior his bread and meat. Once however the line is laid ana trie Lands Department has surveyed some township blocks, the Mallee storekeeper arrives on the scene. Y^Ty/CX3^ liJ thero a branch store of an old established tradesman further back. like the farmer, the Mallee storekeeper h_;o little capital though much confidence, which he apparently is able to inspire in the Flinders lane warehouseman also.

In his store is stocked almost everything required from trace chains to tinned meats, the latest things in clothing and a groat variety of luxuries. Almost as soon open a fruit .and vegetable shop which generally caters also in an inefficient way for the inner man. The "blacksmith lags a little as compared with the earlier days, when duplicates were not so common. Three things, almost essential, are not so easily procured. The first is a Justice of the Peace, as most of the pioneers have left transactions in course "behind them, which require under tho British system much signing of stamped papers. The second is a hall for meetings, generally indignation ones, "but also for social intercourse and the third and always the last is a bank. The tenure given under the existing laws is not a sufficient security to the conservative view of the Victorian banks. In South Australia, it is quite different. There a branch of the Bank of Adelaide is frequently the first building near a railway station. Other requirements are hotels, lawyers, and doctors. The hotel under the present licensing lav/, takes many years before its appearance becomes possible. Whatever its drawbacks, it is an improvement upon the wine saloon which precedes it. lluch may be said in favour of wine as a beverage: but not of the wine sold in these places nor of any wine as a means of getting drunk, for that is the general purpose of its consumption. Neither the lawyer nor the medical man can make a living until the pooulation is over 1200. Allowing one urban for each two rural dwellers, it calls for the settlement of over 150 farms or about 150,000 acres, about lour parishes as they run in Victoria. Government help towards the establishment of a medical man is withheld in this State. The Bush Nursing Association, a private enterprise has stepped into the breach, and has established what are virtually hospitals of quite a high order, although at times the doctor is far distant. No fault can be found with the Postal Depart¬ ment which caters both for mails and telephones with a commendable promptitude. For some reason, it has never entered the official mind to load the township lands in the same way as the farms. If that had been done, a fund would have been created which would have provided the much needed public hall, in itself not a mean revenue producer, helped to make the streets traffickable and to provide a v/ater supply reticulation. When the Onyen-Murrayvllle country

was thrown open in tho years 1909-1912 it formed what may be termed an island settlement, there being no existing settlement in the State in oontaot with it. Much to the sur-orise of no less than six Shires, lawloit, Lowan Dimboola, Xarkarooc, Swan,Hill and LUldura, they found that settlement had taken place in their hinterlands, places absolutely inaccessible to their officials. Hatters carried on somehow or another for a year or two: then e soecial Act was passed creating a new body, the Walpeup Shire Council. The settlers, without municipal experience, responded to the call and very soon demonstrated that new ideas or perhaps, freedom from old shibboleths could be employed to the benefit of all.^ At any rote, no other part of the Mallee country, so quickly was favoured with good roads and urban conveniences. Ouyen forged ahead. With good streets and footpaths,_ electric lighting and sanitation, it became the principal town of the inner Mallee, outstripping all its older- settled competitors.

CHINA'S FOOD PROBLEM A STUDY OF SUPPLY AND CONSUMPTION OF FOOD FOR 14 PROVINCES By C. C. Chang INTRODUCTION The purpose of this paper is to describe in quantitative terms China's supply and consumption of food by taking a sample of 14 provinces for which some reasonably approximate statistics are available. The description confines itself to only 14 provinces because even such approximate statistics are lacking for other parts of the country. It should be noted, however, that the 14 provinces considered here include the greater part of China's most important agricultural regions and have a population totalling up to nearly 280 million which is certainly over half of the entire country. For that reason the conclusions we arrive at from this study may fairly apply to the country as a whole. The basic data used in this study are almost entirely sup¬ plied by the Bureau of Statistics Legislative Yuan, National Gov¬ ernment of China. The nature and methods of collecting- such data will be explained as they are introduced. The provinces included in this study may be located in the attached map. I. FOOD SUPPLY OF 14 PROVINCES. China's food supply in recent years comes from two sources, native production and foreign imports. We shall first consider native production. A. Native Production of Food. Chinese statistics are rare in any field, but the carefully es¬ timated figures on cultivated land and crops made by the Bureau
Af/IPOfCf/W/f .—v. P/?Of//IYC£S IV/TH /V/?AT£S X 1 <4W£> l/AS£S ARE v--.. STUDIED f/io/v//v& vSHJHVSl

of Statistics in the Legislative Yuan, at Nanking, may throw some Light on the question of food production in these 14 provinces. Since 1928 that Bureau has continually sent out simple ques¬ tionaire blanks to hsien (county) magistrates, postmasters, school teachers and individual farmers to inquire about the population, land and crops of every hsien, in as many quantitative terms as the correspondents could reasonably answer. Among other things these blanks asked for the number of farm households, acreage of cultivated land, percentage of the cultivated land usually planted to each of the various crops, and the average rate of yield of each crop per unit of area in normal years. In these schedules the number of farm households and the acreage of cultivated land refer to the time of filling- the schedules but the crop acre¬ age and crop yield refer to the average years. Thus the answers made at different months and years are fairly comparable. When these schedules came in one might find answers to some questions appearing to be wild guesses, but the question¬ naire was made in such a way that the answers to important questions are counter-checked on the schedules themselves. For example, one question is asked about the total area of each hsien to insure that the cultivated land is not more than the entire area. The most common size of a farm area is also asked to check the accuracy of the total cultivated area. When the answered blanks came in their answers were check¬ ed for obvious discrepancies and doubtful points wrere sent back for confirmation. Preliminary tabulation was then made for each item of inquiry and comparison was made between the figures on the blanks and those of other available sources. There were disagreements of course. To determine which figure re¬ presents the actual fact was the most difficult thing; but by rely¬ ing on the related facts such as topography, rainfall, temperature and density of population in and near a locality to which the figures refer one could select a figure that appears to be rather reasonable. Basing our study on information thus secured we shall examine the different aspects of food production in these 14 provinces.

1. Acreage of cultivated land. The total area of these 14 provinces is 4,836 million mow or approximately one million square miles. The cultivated land totals up to 900 million mow or 18% of the entire area. The most important factor that determines the productivity of Chinese farm land excluding Man¬ churia is irrigation. The irrigated land is more productive than the non-irrigated land. For that reason we ihave divided the cultivated land into two main groups, the irrigated and the non- irrigated. The acreage of the irrigated land is about 18% of the total cultivated land and the remaining 82% is not regularly irrigated. Of the 82% non-irrigated land 65% is on plains and the rest on hills. Details of these statistics may be observed from the following table: Table I. Total area and acreage of cultivated land of 14 provinces. Total area in 1,000 mow1 Acreage of cultivated land in 1,000 mow* Regions and Total Irrigated Non-irrigated provinces Level land Hilly land Heilungkiang Kirin Liaoning Jehol Chahar 962,844 458,480 429,430 283,631 409,418 49,407 71,234 71,961 18,147 16,839 377 1,793 878 242 1,855 45,854 56,916 50,541 8,069 7,515 3,176 12,525 20,542 9,836 7,469 Northeast region 2,543,803 227,588 5,145 168,895 53,548 Shansi Hopei Honan Shantung 278,796 224,396 300,291 238,017 60,560 103,432 112,981 110,662 3,629 8,467 7,802 2,395 27,540 88,088 89,915 93,672 299,215 29,391 . 6,877 15,264 14,595 North region 1,041,500 387,635 22,293 66,127 Hupeh Anhwei Kiangsu Chekiang 313,339 235,433 177,029 156,865 61,010 48,812 91,669 41,208 26,273 19,219 35,574 29,806 23,565 25,939 52,486 7,281 11,172 3,654 3,609 4,121 Central region 882,666 242,699 110,872 109,271 22,556 Kwangtung 368,476 42,452 24,690 12,411 589,792 5,351 Grand Total 4,836,445 900,374 163,000 147,582 One mow is approximately one sixth of an acre.

In the above table the 14 provinces are grouped into North East, North, Central and Kwangtung regions, roughly based on similarities in agricultural conditions and density of population. This same grouping is followed throughout in other tables. Taking these provinces by regions the percentages of culti¬ vated land to the total area are 9% for the North East, 37% for the North, 27% for the central and 11% for Kwangtung. One question that interests us in connection with the future food supply of China is how much of the 80% of non-cultivated land of these 14 provinces is economically suitable for cultivation and food production. There is no question that some of it can be profitably reclaimed but the extent of reclamation is certainly limited. In the North East region, especially Manchuria, it is not unreasonable to expect the percentage of cultivated land to go up as high as 20% of the total area but for the rest of these 14 provinces, and of China as a whole, it is highly improbable that the acreage of cultivated land will increase more than 5% of what we have already put under plough. It is true that one can see miles and miles of virgin prairies in some parts of China which may be profitably turned into grain fields, but such places are limited to a few localities only and their area is negligibly small compared with the land that has already been cultivated. On the other hand where one finds the presence of men there one can see cultivation taking place on steep hill sides and narrow river banks. Deserted farms are not rare in the hills of subtropical Kwangtung as well as on mountain ranges of semi-arid Kansu. All these observations seem to indicate that the food producing area of China will not increase to any great extent under the present method of cultiva¬ tion. 2. Crop acreage. The following table II shows how much of the cultivated land is used for food crops and how much for crops of other uses. In the above table the acreage of each of the five classes of crops is shown. The food and feed crops include rice, wheat, barley, millet, kaoliang, corn, peas, etc. They do not include

soybeans, because that crop is not used entirely for food. In the class of seeds for oil, soybeans, rape seeds, flax and sesamum are included. Other classes of crops need no explanation. The average annual acreage of all these crops totals up to 1,128 million mow, which is greater than the total acreage of the cultivated land because of double cropping in regions other than the North East. Food and feed crops share 80% of the total crop acreage; seeds for oil occupy 15.5%; and all the other classes of crops take up only 4.5%. 3. Acreage and production of food crops. Acreage and pro¬ duction of each of the chief food crops are given in Table III by regions. According to the above table, taking the 14 provinces as a whole, wheat comes first in magnitude of acreage but rice leads in quantity of production. In general rice is planted in the irrigated and the best fields and much labor and fertilizers are applied to get the maximum yield per mow. Wheat is not so well treated. That, together with the difference in the natural yield in seed production of these crops, makes rice produce al¬ most three times as much as wheat from the same unit of area. It explains why rice, occupying smaller acreage, produces a larger quantity of food material. 4. Net supply of food from different crops. The above table which we have just reviewed only gives the gross produc¬ tion of various food crops. It does not represent the net food supply derived from them. Some of the crops produced must be used in part or wholly as feeds. From every crop a part of the annual production must be taken out to provide seeds to pro¬ duce the following year's crop. The portion that remains avail¬ able for human food must be processed before it is consumed. In processing some of the foodstuffs go to waste, as for example. hulls of rice and bran of flour. The net supply of food, there¬ fore, is the gross production less the quantities necessary for feed, seed, and wastes in processing. The table following gives the gross production and the net supply of food from various crops of the 14 provinces- (Table IV)

In order to make the quantity of one crop com¬ parable to that of another each crop is expressed in terms of rice equivalent calculated on the basis of the fuel value of each crop in proportion to that of middle grade of rice.(1) Quantities of feed required by each province are taken out from such crops as the farmers ordinarily use in that province. According to the above table the total supply of food of all the 17 chief crops amounts to 107,438, million catties or 143,216 million pounds per year of rice equivalent. Rice, wheat, kaoliang, millet and corn make up about 85% of the total supply. The remaining 20% is distributed among 12 minor crops as the table shows. In the table we have not included soybeans because this crop is largely used for industrial purposes. But it is well known that some of this crop is also directly consumed as human food. To find the total food supply it seems necessary to include some of that crop. The gross production of soybeans in million catties per year by provinces and regions is as follows: Heilungkiang 2,293 Hupeh 787 Kirin 3,818 Anhwei 1,070 Liaoning 2,488 Kiangsu 2.295 Jehol 184 Chekiang 348 Chahar 109 Central 4,500 North East 8,892 Kwangtung 199 Shansi 267 Hopei 1,119 Honan 1,474 Shantung 3,484 North 6,344 Total 19,935 (!) Of the 8,892 million catties of soybeans produced in the North East Provinces about 3,500' million catties are exported, 3,000 million catties abroad and 500 million catties to other parts of China. The remainder is used as seed, feed and for in¬ dustrial purposes. The amount that goes to direct food con¬ sumption must be very negligible compared with the gross pro¬ duction. For that reason we shall not include any soybeans in our calculation of total food supply for this region. Utilization of soybeans in other provinces is different. More than 90% of the gross production goes to domestic consumption. It is hard to say, however, how much of it goes to sup¬ ply human food and how much is used for industries. Not going into detailed discussion on this question for lack of information we shall arbitrarily take 40% of the gross production as the portion that is used directly as human food, for regions other than the North East. U. FOOD CONSUMPTION How much food is normally required by these 14 provinces in a year is the question that we attempt to answer in this section. To answer this question two factors must be known, the total population and the average food requirement per person. We shall consider the second factor first. Average amount of food required by an average' Chinese person per day. On the average food requirement of a Chinese person, some studies have been made in the past. The results of some well known studies may be tabulated here. From the above table one finds that the fuel value required by an adult male per day varies somewhere from 2600 to 3500 calories. We do not know which is the best figure to take, but one thing stands out clearly, that the proportion of fuel value derived from cereal products is much higher than that supplied by other kinds of food. This is more conspicuous in the case of farm diet. Professor Buck's results show a proportion of 90% and Mr. Yashnoff's 97% of the fuel value supplied by cereal products. The working people in the cities get a larger proportion of their fuel value from other foods than the farmers. It seems safe to say that from 90 to 95% of the nutritive value of the diet of most people in the Northern provinces are obtained from cereal pro¬ ducts. In the South more variety is found but still the larger por¬ tion, from 80 to 95% of the nutritive value comes from cereals and tubers. This condition simplifies the method of studying Chinese food requirement. If one can get a fair idea of the average cereal requirement, one has the large part of the food demand deter¬ mined. Under the auspices of the Bureau of Statistics of the Legis¬ lative Yuan, the author conducted a study of the average daily re¬ quirement of rice per person in the fall of 1930. Two samples were taken, one in the country about 15 miles east of Nanking and another in a small town about 10 miles south of the same city. In the country district, 2389 persons answered their inquiries and in the town 2047 persons responded. The coun¬ try people are those of the farm families. The towns people are from the families of businessmen, handicraft men, and school teach¬ ers. The method of investigation may be sketched briefly. A blank schedule was used for each family to be investigated. In the schedule, five items were asked of each person of the family, namelly (1) relation to head of family, (2) sex, (3) age, (4) occupa¬ tion and (5) number of bowls of cooked rice ordinarily consumed per day. For the entire family this question was asked : "How many catties of uncooked rice are needed per day for preparing enough cooked rice for all members in the family if they all take their meals at home?" Answers to this question give the total quantity of rice

consumed by all members and the amount consumed by each mem¬ ber is apportioned according to the number of bowls he or she takes. For example, one family has 4 members. The total amount of rice consumed in a day is 4.5 catties. The four members give the following answers: Relation to head of family Sex Age No. of bowls of rice consumed Bigd) Small Equivalent to oz. of uncooked rice (calculated) Head of family Wife Son Daughter male female male female 49 45 19 15 3 0 4 0 0 4 0 6 18 12 24 18 Total 10 72 The four members consume in all 7 big bowls and 10 small bowls of cooked rice which was made from 4.5 catties or 72 oz. of uncooked rice. Since one big bowl contains twice the amount of one small bowl the head of the family consumed 6 small bowls and the son 8 small bowls. That makes a total of ( 6+8+4+6') 24 small bowls of uncooked rice for the entire family. These 24 bowls of cooked rice were prepared from 72 oz. of uncooked rice and therefore one small bowl of cooked rice is equal to three oz. That makes the daily consumption of uncooked rice for the four members as follows: Head of family 6 x 3=18 oz. Wife 4 x 3=12 „ Son 8 x 3=24 „ Daughter 6 x 3=18 ,, Total 72 oz. or 4.5 catties The above example illustrates the underlying principle of the questionaire and the method of calculation. The blank schedules were filled by an investigator of long experience. The results were sorted according to sex and age. For persons in each one-year age group of either sex an average was calculated for the daily requirement. These one-year (!) One big bowl equals two small bowls in capacity.

Ordinarily the diet of the farmers con¬ sists of a larger proportion of cereals than that of the town people. Meats, fish and even leafy vegetables are not always available on Chinese farms. Average per capita daily rice requirement of town population: We shall use the same method to calculate the average per-capita daily rice requirement of the city population some data are avail¬ able in the Bureau of Statistics, Legislative Yuan. Using those data and the results of the daily food requirement studied by the same Bureau we have the following table: According to the above table the daily rice requirement of a city man is 18.19 Chinese ounces and that of a woman is 15.84 ounces. In terms of grams the city male requires 642 grams and the female, 559 grams. That gives a fuel value of 2266 calories, and 1974 calories per day for city man and city woman respectively. The city woman requires about 87% of the amount of rice that is required by a city man. The foregoing results may be summarized as follows: Daily requirement Persons In local Chinese ounces t1) In catties <2) In grams In calories (3) Country male City male City female 23.31 20.38 18.19 15.84 1.372 823 1.200 720 1.070 559 0.932 559 2906' 25.42 2266 1974 In the above table it may be observed that the average man on the farm requires about 20% more rice than the man in the city; the farm women requires also about 20% more than the city woman. On the basis of these results we shall proceed to find out how much food is normally required by these 14 provinces. Total food requirement of the 14 provinces. To determine the total food requirement of these provinces we have to deal with the much disputed question of the number of the Chinese popula¬ tion. How many people are there in these provinces? We must (!) One local Chinese ounce is 35.31 grams. (2) One catty=600 grams. (3) One catty (600 grams) of medium grade rice gives about 2118 calories.

admit that this question cannot yet be answered entirely with figures secured by modern census taking, but the figures we adopt here should not be very far from the fact. Among the 14 provinces under our present consideration eight had population census re¬ turns for the number of males and females for 1928. The remaining six provinces have reported their estimated numbers of households but not numbers of persons. The method we use to obtain the number of persons of a province (which does not give the numbers of persons) is to multiply the number of households by the average number of persons per household of the neighboring province or provinces. Thus the total number of persons in Kirin Province is obtained by multiplying Kirin's total number of household, 1,260,907, by the 6.67, which is the average number of persons per household of Liaoning Province, a near neighbor to Kirin. The product 8,410,250 is taken as the total population of Kirin. It is a rough estimate but that seems to be the best that wte can do. The following table gives the population by regions and provinces: In the above table we have assumed that the number of persons per farm household is equal to that of the city household. Observation shows, however, that the city household has a smaller number of persons than the farm household. If this observation is correct the above table shows too large a population for citiesr and too small a one for the country. Since the city people require considerably smaller amount of rice than the country folks our calculation of total food requirement based on the above popula¬ tion estimates will give a smaller figure than it should be. No attempt is made to correct that error. We can only ask our readers to give due attention to that point. The total annual food requirement of each province is cal¬ culated by multiplying the number of each class of population by the average amount of the annual per capita rice requirement of that class. The results of these calculations are shown in the table below:

According to the above table the 14 provinces normally need 124,565 million catties or 83 million short tons of rice or rice equivalent per annum. The total supply of food including the excess of imports over exports as we have already calculated is 118,532 million catties or 79 million short tons. The supply of food therefore is about four million tons or 5% less than the estimated requirement. If our data were all absolutely reliable and our methods of calculation all justified, this 5% difference in supply and demand would mean that the population of these provinces are underfed to that degree. But that cannot be the case. As we have explained in the preceding pages it is not at all strange to find our data 10% too high or too low for the real facts. Our results should Table X. not be taken as more refined than that limit. The only conclusion it seems safe to draw is that in normal crop years these pro¬ vinces have just about enough food supply. Having determined the production and the requirement of food it is a simple matter to find out which provinces and regions have sufficient supply and which insufficient. This may be observ¬ ed from the following table. In the above table it is clearly shown that the provinces in the North East Region produce more food than their populations require. Shansi, Hupeh and Kiangsu are self-sufficient. All other provinces are definitely deficient in their food production. Among the deficient provinces Kwangtung stands at the top. Her pro¬ duction can support only two thirds of her population; the other one third must be fed with imported food stuffs. For the North Region the deficient amount of food is about 20% of the total requirement; the same kind of figure for the central region is 10%. Taking all these provinces as a whole and balancing up the total amount of deficiency by that of surplus wre still have a deficiency of 12,000 million catties of rice or rice equivalent per year, forming about 8% of the total requirement. The foregoing statements may not express the exact amount of food deficiency or surplus of each province but the tendencies they show cannot be far wrong. We may also remind the reader that the vast number (500,000 to 1,000,000) of people who emigrate to the North East Pro¬ vinces every year are mostly from the North region. Some of these immigrants go there for fortune but most of them go there for food.

SUMMARY 1. The proportion of the cultivated land of the 14 provinces that is normally devoted to production of food and feed is about 80%. 2. In the 14 provinces studied, rice, wheat, kaoliang, millet and corn are the most important food crops. They make up about 85% of the total food supply. 3. The total annual supply of food is 118,532 million catties in rice equivalent. Of that quantity the supply coming from foreign countries, after balancing up with food exports, is less than two percent. 4. The average annual per capita food supply is estimated at about 426 catties or 568 pounds in rice equivalent. 5. The total consumption of food based on the estimated popula¬ tion (278 millions) of these provinces is 124,565 million catties in rice equivalent. 6. When supply is compared with consumption requirements the former is about 5% less than the latter. 7. Among the four regions, the North East produces more food than it consumes. The other regions are not producing enough food for their population.

A Study of Correlation Between Factors of Production and the Yields of Arable Land Prefared for the Fourth Bi-annual Conference of the Institute of Pacific Relations to be held at Hangchow from Oct. 2 ist—Nov. 4th, 1931. By SHIROSHI NASU, D. Agr. Professor Tokyo Imperial University Published by The Japan Council of the Institute of Pacific Relations Boeki-Kaikan, Ginza Nishi Nana-chome, Kyobashi-ku, TOKYO, JAPAN

A STUDY OF CORRELATION BETWEEN FACTORS OF PRODUCTION AND THE YIELDS OF ARABLE LAND The following may be said to be the principal factors that are responsible for the differences in productivity due to the loca¬ tion and the utilization of arable land in Japan: (1) Natural factors such as topographical, geological and climatic. (2) Industrial factors. (a) The degree of intensity of labor and of labor technique. (b) The degree of intensity of capital. ( i) The amount and method of current invest¬ ment: the degree of intensity and technique in the application of fertilizers and farm implements. (ii) The amount and method of previous funda¬ mental investment: capital aready put into the arable land in order to increase its pro¬ ductivity. (3) Social-economic factors such as: (a) the size of markets. (b) the distance between the farm and the market. (c) the means of transportation available. The interdependence of these main factors is a deciding factor in the utilization and productivity of arable land. It must be noted that factors in (1): and (3) are, when viewed from the standpoint of industrial management, given a priori. ' The factor (2) can be artificially modified only in relation to the other two factors, namely, (1) and (3). We shall take these two other factors in

the present condition in our country as given facts, in the present inquiry into the correlations between the various factors of agricul¬ tural management and both the form of utilization and yields of arable land. Let us first classfy the different grades of labor intensity which may be applied to a given kind of arable land, and then calculate respectively according to that classification the average amount of yield per tan of the arable land. We will then find the total field of all the arable lands in the entire country having the same inten¬ sity of labor. In this calculation, we may consider that all other factors in each kind of arable land have been distributed equally. We can thus learn the amount of yield per tan that corresponds to each grade of labor intensity. We may then calculate the relation between the amount of labor put into arable land and the crop yield. The same process of investigation will show the correlations between the amount of fertilizer put into arable land and its yield. The correlations between the depth of ploughing, which depends on such a factors as the nature of the soil and the amount of labor expended, and the productivity, of the land. By this method, we can study the importance which each of such factors of agricultural management as the amount of labor, fertilizers, and the depth of the ploughing bears to the differences of yield in this country. The following is the result of our investigation. A. Why is it then that this general rule does not apply in this case? It is because of the peculiar agricultural circumstances which exist in Japan, that is: (1) In this country some paddy fields are situated in deep muddy places often reaching several feet in depth. Such paddy fields, which are called "Fuketa," by the nature of things, make deep ploughing invitable. It is impossible to carry on both irriga¬ tion and drainage properly, and therefore such paddy fields are wet throughout the entire year. They exist in mountain valleys and other places where under-ground water runs on high levels. (2) Moreover, our one sided rice diet plays a peculiar role in this respect. Our farmers raise rice even where no ordinary means of irrigation exist. In such cases, the land is ploughed deeply so that more water may be absorbed. In order to hold sufficient water for the summer rice culture, no drainage is made even during the winter months. Therefore they are wet throughout the year. In these unfavorable paddy field it is not possible to adjust the irrigation, a factor which is most important in raising rice. The water is always coldj its circulation is\ badj and the dirt of the paddyfields is not exposed to the air. The results are that the rice roots are not sufficiently stimulated and the dissolution of fertilizers is imperfect. Therefore it is inevitable that the crop is poor. Because of these peculiar agricultural circumstances in Japan, it cannot be said that rice paddies taken as a whole may yield more because they are ploughed deeper. TABLE III. Correlations Between the Amount of Labor Used and the Yield of Arable Land It is generally conceded that the greater the intensification of labor, the more will be the yield of arable land. But our investiga¬ tion into the raising of rice on paddy fields embodied in Table V and Diagram V shows the correlation coefficient r = 0.26, thus showing that where -the large amount of labor is used the size of the crop is not necessarily large. The result of the investiga¬ tion in the case of the upland fields where barley and sweet potatoes are raised alternatively gives r=0.49 (Table VI and Diagram VI). The reasons for these correlations being so extremely limited needs explanation. A study of paddy fields reveals two fundamental reasons: (a) Because of Japanese one-sided rice diet, farmers raise rice even where its cultivation is greatly handicapped. This means that often in the cultivation of this cereal, the crop hardly justifies the amount of labor required. (b) Labor surplus in our agricultural villages. Labor is more plentiful than all the other factors of production in our farm management and is therefore incredibly cheap. The methods used, however, have been the best that are available. Moreover, the amount of fertilizer affects the yield with mathematical precision only when all other factors are equal and when the fertilizers themselves are of the same definite quality. By "quality" is meant not only all of the three organic and other content but also their inter-relations, the speed of their dissolution, and the time of application. As I have explained elsewhere (on the irrationality in the use of fertilizers), there is a deep and complicated defect in the method of using fertilizers in our country at present. It often happens that plants are injured by the wrong use of fertilizers. The amount of yield may even be reduced instead of increased. Nor does this defect seem to apply in the same way everywhere. The results of the investigation will be satisfactory if it reveals in a rough outline the correlations between the amount of fertilizer and the yield under the present management of arable land in this country.
