Correlations Between the Depth of Ploughing and the Amount of Yield of Arable Land in our Country The correlations in the case of paddy fields are shown in Table III and Diagram III. The results of our investigation show that the depth of ploughing does not bear any necessary relationship to the amount of the crop. The correlation co-efficient r = 0.29 indicates that there is no connection between them. This however, has nothing to do with the case where a different depth of plough¬ ing is practised on the same land. As a general proposition, it is undeniable that the greater the depth of the ploughing, the more will be the amount of the crop. When land is ploughed deeper, a more satisfactory amount of water and nurishment can be had and the growth of t'he roots will be promoted. The writer has al¬ ready discussed this in his "Examples of the Effects Deep Plough¬ ing Has on the Productivity of Arable Land" and "Conditions Responsible for Maximum Production" (given in Table IV and Diagram IV). This is also seen in the result of another in¬ vestigation which showed that where the rotated cultivation of barley and sweet potatoes is practiced in upland fields the correla¬ tion coefficient r=0.96 existed between the depth of ploughing and the yield (given in Table IV and Diagram IV).

This is further demonstrated by the fact that the productivity of arable land in the districts near cities and towns is higher than the average of the whole country, in spite of the comparatively smaller amount of labor expended in agriculture. This is true because the greater demand for and higher price of labor result in a higher efficiency. Average Yield Number of Per Tan ^in Koku) Men engaged Average of 37 urban districts in Japan ................... 2.41 20 Average of 370 rural districts. . . . 2.39 22 It may therefore be said that the Japanese paddy fields show the highest productive efficiency in the world, chiefly because of the abundance of labor. However, we cannot say that the local differences in yield under present paddy conditions of Japan is con¬ trolled by the amount of labor expended. The same condition of an over supply of labor is also true of upland fields. Where there is scarcity of labor, all labor newly applied be¬ comes effective, and the amount of output varies with the amount of labor available. Under such circumstances, the rationalization of agricultural management may be attained by the greater applica¬ tion of machinery and the use of beasts of burden. But where there exists a sort of surplus labor, as in our country today—there is an undoubted surplus of labor in the raising of rice—and where labor is a surplus element in the "law of minimum," all sorts of labor will be reduced in its efficiency. The greater the amount of labor surplus, the lower will be the efficiency of the labor unit. As the labor surplus decreases, labor efficiency increases. Viewed from the standpoint of the rationalization of agricultural manage¬ ment, it is often possible that, unless the types of farming are radically altered, the employment of beasts of burden or the use of machinery would result in a higher cost than when man power only is utilized.

The existence of an agricultural industry that depends solely on human labor such as we have in our country today is the inevit¬ able result of a labor surplus rather than of an ignorance or ineffi¬ ciency of the farmers. Thus, in this country, the amount of labor power has ceased to have any special influence upon the output of farms. Of course, the quality of labor (skill and technical knowledge) still retains its great significance, but this question cannot be discussed here. There is one more point to be mentioned. So far we have discussed only cases having the same types of farming. There would be a different picture, if the types of farming or the utiliza¬ tion of arable land could be changed. By increasing the number of rotation crops, or by changing the plant raised, a stated area in a given district could absorb more labor. There is a vast pos¬ sibility in this country of increasing the output per tan by changing the farm organization, and thereby adjusting the seasonal distri¬ bution of labor required. TABLE V.
